criterion_scores.justification: For 37–100 U/mL, cites benign causes including pancreatitis and gallstones/bile duct obstruction.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that moderate elevation (100-1000 U/mL) can be concerning for cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States 100–1,000 U/mL is "more concerning for cancer," especially pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that levels greater than 1000 U/mL can be suggestive of advanced cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Says >1,000 U/mL is "strongly suggestive of advanced cancer," particularly metastatic pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the use of CA 19-9 in pancreatic cancer, including that it can be a marker of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies CA 19-9 as a tumor marker used especially for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated in other conditions.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes elevations in multiple benign conditions (pancreatitis, cholestasis, liver disease, IBD) and other cancers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used for monitoring the effectiveness of pancreatic cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains trend use during treatment: rises may mean treatment failure; drops suggest response after therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used for detecting recurrence of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly mention use for detecting recurrence.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used in other cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions use/elevation in bile duct, gallbladder, colorectal, stomach, and liver cancers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated in liver disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists liver diseases such as cirrhosis and hepatitis as causes of elevated CA 19-9.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated in gallstones.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions gallstones as a benign cause of mild elevation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated with elevated bilirubin.
criterion_scores.justification: While bile duct obstruction/cholestasis is mentioned, elevated bilirubin is not explicitly referenced.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 is not produced by all pancreatic cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: States that 20–30% of pancreatic cancer patients have normal CA 19-9, implying not all tumors produce/raise the marker.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists acute and chronic pancreatitis under benign pancreatic conditions that can raise CA 19-9.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with liver diseases like cirrhosis or hepatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly mentions cirrhosis and hepatitis (viral, alcoholic, autoimmune) as causes of elevated CA 19-9.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with cholestasis or biliary diseases.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes biliary obstruction (gallstones, strictures, choledocholithiasis), cholangitis, primary biliary cholangitis, and primary sclerosing cholangitis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with inflammatory bowel disease or gastrointestinal diseases.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically lists inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn’s, ulcerative colitis) and other GI disorders such as gastritis and peptic ulcers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with infections or other inflammatory conditions.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes infections (e.g., cholangitis, severe infections) and inflammatory/autoimmune conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, endometriosis) as causes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be a marker of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States CA 19-9 is commonly associated with pancreatic cancer and used for diagnosis, monitoring, and detecting recurrence.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used in other cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple non-pancreatic malignancies (biliary tract, colorectal, gastric, esophageal, hepatocellular, ovarian, lung, breast, endometrial, etc.).

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 is not produced by all pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States that 5–10% of people (Lewis antigen negative) do not produce CA 19-9 even if they have cancer, covering non-production in some pancreatic cancers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing weight loss with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises to consult the oncology team and an oncology dietitian for personalized advice and to contact the doctor for significant weight loss or other concerning symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme replacement can be taken to help with the absorption of nutrients from foods.
criterion_scores.justification: States that pancreatic enzyme supplements (e.g., Creon) may be prescribed and explains they help break down fats and proteins to improve absorption and reduce symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that nutritional strategies can be employed, such as focusing on small, frequent meals and nutrient-rich foods, and should recommend including calorie-dense and protein-rich foods in the diet.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends small, frequent meals; emphasizes calorie-dense, nutrient-rich foods; and lists protein-rich options and healthy fats to increase intake.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that medications for managing nausea can be helpful.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically notes anti-nausea medications such as ondansetron can help and advises discussing with the doctor.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state there are many causes of weight loss in patients with pancreatic cancer, including weight loss related to chemotherapy side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes multiple causes of weight loss, explicitly including effects from treatments like chemotherapy, radiation, and surgery, and side effects such as nausea and vomiting.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state there are many causes of weight loss in patients with pancreatic cancer, including weight loss related to pancreatic enzyme deficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that pancreatic cancer can cause pancreatic enzyme deficiency leading to malabsorption and weight loss, and discusses enzyme replacement as management.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include unintentional weight loss.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists 'Unintended Weight Loss: Significant weight loss without trying.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include jaundice.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes 'Jaundice (Yellowing of the Skin and Eyes)'.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include new onset diabetes.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'New-Onset Diabetes or Worsening of Existing Diabetes'.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include abdominal pain.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'Abdominal or Back Pain: A dull, persistent pain in the upper abdomen...'.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic cancer can be difficult to detect early.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes it is a 'silent' disease with few early symptoms and 'Early Detection is Rare'.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic cancer does not cause symptoms until the disease is advanced.
criterion_scores.justification: Says it may not cause noticeable symptoms in early stages and that people are often diagnosed at a later stage, implying symptoms typically appear when disease is advanced.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state the reason for jaundice is the blockade of bile ducts.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains jaundice occurs 'when the tumor blocks the bile duct, leading to a buildup of bilirubin.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that loss of appetite can be a symptom.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions weight loss 'often accompanied by loss of appetite.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that abdominal bloating or indigestion can be a symptom.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'indigestion' among digestive issues.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that foul-smelling stools or steatorrhea can be a symptom.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes 'fatty stools that float,' which describes steatorrhea.

criterion_scores.description: The response should reference the American Cancer Society information page on symptoms of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: References the American Cancer Society as a source for the information provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that most pancreatic cancer cases are sporadic and not hereditary.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that 90–95% of pancreatic cancers are sporadic and not inherited.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there are hereditary conditions that can lead to pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly notes that 5–10% of cases are hereditary and discusses inherited mutations that increase risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a strong family history is a significant risk factor.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that a strong family history can raise risk 2–10 times and provides examples of family history patterns.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including familial pancreatic cancer syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: While multiple syndromes are listed, the response does not explicitly identify familial pancreatic cancer (FPC) syndrome by name.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including BRCA1/BRCA2 mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: BRCA1/BRCA2 (HBOC) are explicitly mentioned with context on increased pancreatic cancer risk, especially BRCA2.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including Lynch syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Lynch syndrome is included with mention of mismatch repair genes (MLH1, MSH2).

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is identified with STK11.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including Familial atypical multiple mole melanoma.
criterion_scores.justification: FAMMM syndrome is included with CDKN2A.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including hereditary pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Hereditary (familial) pancreatitis is explicitly mentioned with PRSS1.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if you are concerned about your risk of pancreatic cancer, you should consult an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It directly recommends consulting an oncologist for personalized advice.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if you are concerned about your risk of pancreatic cancer, you should consult a genetic counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly advises consulting a genetic counselor and discusses genetic testing considerations.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that routine screening is not recommended for the general population.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states, "there is no routine screening recommended for the general population" and explains why.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention MRI as a surveillance modality for high-risk individuals.
criterion_scores.justification: MRI/MRCP is described as a preferred modality for initial and follow-up screening in high-risk individuals.

criterion_scores.description: The response must specify that surveillance typically starts around age 50 and continues annually.
criterion_scores.justification: It states surveillance typically begins around age 40–50 and mentions annual surveillance (e.g., NCCN suggests annual EUS/MRI starting at age 40–50). This satisfies the intent of starting around 50 with annual follow-up.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that the evidence for screening/surveillance is not well established and mention the risk of overdiagnosis leading to unnecessary stress and procedures.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes "insufficient evidence" in some populations (AGA) and "no proven mortality reduction," and explicitly discusses overdiagnosis, false positives, unnecessary biopsies/surgeries, and anxiety.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that people at high risk may benefit from screening.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states surveillance is targeted at high-risk individuals where benefits may outweigh risks and cites improved early-stage detection in high-risk groups.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define people at high risk of pancreatic cancer to include those with a significant family history of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It defines high risk to include individuals with multiple first-degree relatives affected or early-onset in a first-degree relative.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define people at high risk of pancreatic cancer to include those with a known genetic syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists multiple hereditary syndromes (e.g., Peutz-Jeghers, Lynch, FAMMM/CDKN2A, BRCA1/2, PALB2, ATM) as high-risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define people at high risk of pancreatic cancer to include those with a history of chronic pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Chronic pancreatitis, especially hereditary forms, is included under risk factors considered for surveillance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include EUS as a screening modality to detect pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is described in detail as a sensitive modality for detecting small abnormalities and enabling biopsy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend people discuss the risks and benefits of screening with a doctor.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises consulting a healthcare professional and discussing whether surveillance is appropriate.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend people discuss the risks and benefits of screening with a genetic counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends genetic testing and counseling and advises discussing genetic counseling when considering surveillance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include surgery as a potential treatment modality for resectable pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly describes surgery as the only potentially curative option, details Whipple, distal pancreatectomy, total pancreatectomy, and mentions adjuvant/neoadjuvant approaches.

criterion_scores.description: The response should specify that chemotherapy is the backbone of treatment for metastatic or unresectable pancreatic cancer, with main regimens being FOLFIRINOX or Gemcitabine + Nab-Paclitaxel.
criterion_scores.justification: States chemotherapy is a mainstay for advanced/metastatic disease and explicitly lists FOLFIRINOX and gemcitabine plus nab-paclitaxel as key regimens.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include radiation as a potential treatment option for localized pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes radiation therapy (EBRT, SBRT) and its role in locally advanced disease, often with chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the stage of the disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes treatment depends on stage (resectable, borderline resectable, locally advanced, metastatic) and tailors modalities accordingly.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the co-morbidities of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: States treatment depends on the patient's overall health and age; discussion of regimen selection for "fit patients" implies consideration of comorbidities.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the functional status of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions using FOLFIRINOX for fit patients with good performance status, indicating treatment selection based on functional status.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include immunotherapy, noting its role is currently limited to patients with mismatch repair deficiency or high microsatellite instability.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes pembrolizumab for MSI-H/dMMR tumors and notes immunotherapy has limited success overall in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include targeted therapy such as PARPi for patients with BRCA mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies PARP inhibitors (e.g., olaparib) for BRCA-mutated tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should introduce the concept of clinical trials and their role in the management of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes clinical trials, lists examples of investigational approaches, and provides resources for trial identification.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage 0 is a pre-cancer state, also known as pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia or carcinoma in situ.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly identifies Stage 0 as PanIN/Tis (tumor in situ), explains that abnormal cells are confined to the lining without invasion, indicating a pre-cancer state.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage 1 cancer is when the cancer is confined to the pancreas and has not spread to lymph nodes or distant sites.
criterion_scores.justification: States that Stage I is confined to the pancreas with no spread to lymph nodes or distant sites.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that stage 1a is when the tumor is 2cm or smaller.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states Stage IA is a tumor 2 cm or smaller.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that stage 1b is when the tumor is larger than 2cm.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states Stage IB is larger than 2 cm and limited to the pancreas.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage II is when the cancer is growing into nearby tissues and into lymph nodes.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes Stage II as involving nearby tissues and/or lymph nodes, and details IIA (tissues, no nodes) and IIB (nodes, with or without nearby tissue involvement).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage III is when the cancer is locally advanced and involves surrounding structures.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines Stage III as locally advanced with involvement of major nearby blood vessels and possibly lymph nodes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage IV is when the cancer has spread to other organs or sites.
criterion_scores.justification: States Stage IV includes metastasis to distant organs such as liver, lungs, peritoneum, or bones.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of the T, N, M staging system.
criterion_scores.justification: Introduces the AJCC TNM system and defines T (tumor size/extent), N (lymph nodes), and M (metastasis).

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that pancreatic cancer is categorized by resectability.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes classification by resectability: resectable, borderline resectable, locally advanced (unresectable), or metastatic, and its influence on treatment decisions.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy is a common side effect from the oxaliplatin in FOLFIRINOX.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that the oxaliplatin component is the main culprit behind peripheral neuropathy in FOLFIRINOX.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that the oncologist can ‘hold’ or temporarily stop oxaliplatin to manage neuropathy.
criterion_scores.justification: States, “The oncologist might pause oxaliplatin temporarily,” directly addressing holding the drug.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by dose reduction.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that oncologists might try “dose reductions” to manage neuropathy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by schedule modification.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions treatment “delays” and temporarily pausing oxaliplatin, both reflecting schedule modification.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by switching to an alternate regimen.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends switching to a different regimen if neuropathy is severe and lists alternatives.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by switching to an alternate regimen, including gemcitabine-based therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically lists gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel and gemcitabine alone as alternatives.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including gabapentin.
criterion_scores.justification: Names gabapentin as a medication that can help with nerve pain.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including SNRIs.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists duloxetine (Cymbalta), an SNRI, as a treatment option for neuropathy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including pregabalin.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions pregabalin as a supportive medication for neuropathy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing medication side effects with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises to talk to the oncologist urgently and to make treatment decisions in consultation with the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be informed about the aim of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly explains what clinical trials are and their purposes, and explicitly advises to ask, 'What phase is the trial, and what's its goal?' which addresses knowing the trial’s aim.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should understand the potential benefits of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists benefits such as access to new treatments, close monitoring, potential improved outcomes, and contributing to research.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should understand the potential risks of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Details risks including lack of efficacy, unknown/serious side effects, possibility of placebo/standard care, time burden, and emotional stress.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the inclusion and exclusion criteria for the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a dedicated 'Eligibility' section noting criteria such as stage, prior treatments, overall health, and genetic markers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the time commitments associated with participating in the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions time commitments like frequent visits, travel, additional tests, and advises asking about trial duration and follow-up.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the costs associated with participating in the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses costs and logistics, insurance coverage (ACA), and potential financial aid; clarifies what may or may not be covered.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the phase of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains Phases 1–4 in detail and advises to ask 'What phase is the trial?'

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding if there are crossover options.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention crossover options or advise asking whether crossover is available from control to experimental arm.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used before surgery to help shrink borderline resectable tumors, with the goal of increasing the likelihood of achieving a complete resection in the localized setting.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly discusses neoadjuvant radiation/chemoradiation for borderline resectable tumors to shrink the tumor and make surgery safer/effective and convert inoperable to operable, which aligns with increasing the chance of complete resection.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used for locally advanced or unresectable tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states that for locally advanced/unresectable disease, radiation may be used alongside chemotherapy to control tumor growth and is common in stage III.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used in the palliative setting to relieve symptoms in patients with advanced or metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes a dedicated palliative section for stage IV disease, noting symptom relief (pain, jaundice, bowel obstruction) and shorter courses, matching palliative intent.

criterion_scores.description: Pancreatic cancer treatment plans are determined by the stage of the disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Under 'Factors Influencing the Decision,' it explicitly notes that stage guides use of radiation (more likely in localized stages I–III than metastatic).

criterion_scores.description: Pancreatic cancer treatment plans are determined by the overall health of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that comorbidities/overall health may prompt adjustments to avoid complications, indicating patient health affects planning.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to sterilize vessel margins.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response mentions tumors near major blood vessels and shrinking to enable surgery, it does not state the specific goal of sterilizing vessel margins.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to delay disease progression.
criterion_scores.justification: For locally advanced/unresectable disease, it notes aims to control tumor growth and potentially extend life, which reflects delaying progression in a localized (non-metastatic) setting.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to prevent local recurrence.
criterion_scores.justification: In the adjuvant section, it states postoperative radiation may target microscopic residual disease to lower the risk of recurrence, consistent with preventing local recurrence.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic cancer leads to enzyme deficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that pancreatic cancer (and its treatments) can reduce pancreatic enzyme production, leading to pancreatic exocrine insufficiency (PEI).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how enzyme deficiency can lead to problems with digestion.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that lack of enzymes causes malabsorption and lists specific digestive problems: steatorrhea, bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies, linking enzyme roles (lipase, protease, amylase) to digestion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme supplements are used to replace the enzymes.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly states that enzyme supplements replace the missing enzymes and describes them as prescription pancrelipase products designed to mimic natural pancreatic enzyme output.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme supplements can improve digestion.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly notes that supplements improve digestion and nutrient absorption, reduce gastrointestinal symptoms, and enhance quality of life.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cancer is associated with an increased risk of developing blood clots.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly states that cancer is strongly associated with venous thromboembolism and notes that people with cancer are 4–7 times more likely to develop clots, demonstrating the increased risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that patients with pancreatic cancer are at increased risk of developing a blood clot.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly identifies pancreatic cancer as one of the highest-risk cancers for thrombosis, citing figures (up to 20–30% of patients) and explaining mechanisms, thereby meeting the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that second opinions can be obtained at any time, including after diagnosis, before starting treatment, during treatment, or when considering clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: The answer advises seeking a second opinion right after diagnosis and before treatment, and explicitly states, “It’s never too late… even if treatment has started,” covering during-treatment timing. It also ties second opinions to clinical trials by suggesting asking about trials and noting a second opinion might uncover eligibility. Collectively, this communicates availability at any time, including when considering trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that second opinions are particularly helpful after the initial diagnosis and before starting treatment, as well as when the initial treatment is no longer effective.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly highlights seeking a second opinion after initial diagnosis and before starting treatment. However, it does not explicitly state the scenario of when initial treatment is no longer effective; it only mentions “if progress isn’t as expected,” which is not an explicit reference to treatment failure or no longer effective therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding the diagnosis.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states second opinions are recommended if the diagnosis feels uncertain or incomplete, directly addressing lack of clarity about the diagnosis.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding staging.
criterion_scores.justification: It specifically cites “unclear staging” as a reason to seek a second opinion, meeting the requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding the treatment plan.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions seeking a second opinion if “the proposed treatment plan seems aggressive, unclear,” satisfying this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that second opinions can be obtained at specialized referral centers, such as cancer centers with expertise in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The answer directs users to specialists in pancreatic cancer and high-volume/academic centers, and it highlights cancer centers with specific expertise, fulfilling this requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that they should look up NCI-designated cancer centers specifically.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends NCI-Designated Cancer Centers and provides cancer.gov as a resource, which directly meets the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention major academic hospitals as a resource for finding pancreatic cancer specialists.
criterion_scores.justification: It names major academic hospitals (e.g., Johns Hopkins, Cleveland Clinic) and university-affiliated centers, fully meeting the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that the NCCN guidelines for Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma recommend evaluation at high volume centers.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of NCCN guidelines or their recommendation for evaluation at high-volume centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immunotherapy is currently limited to patients with mismatch repair deficiency or high microsatellite instability.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly states that immunotherapy effectiveness in pancreatic cancer is generally limited and highlights MSI-H/dMMR tumors (~1–2%) as the key exception, noting FDA approval of pembrolizumab for MSI-H/dMMR solid tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immunotherapy is an ongoing area of research.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions ongoing research into combinations (chemo, radiation, vaccines), references early results, and cites emerging approaches like CAR-T and bispecific antibodies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that there may be clinical trial options exploring novel immunotherapies.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises exploring clinical trials, references the NCI and ClinicalTrials.gov, and notes trials testing combination immunotherapy strategies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immune checkpoint blockade is only approved for patients with metastatic disease in certain situations.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions tumor-agnostic approval for MSI-H/dMMR, it does not specify the restriction to unresectable or metastatic disease nor clarify the situational nature of this approval.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pembrolizumab is approved for patients whose tumors are TMB high.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it notes that high TMB may make immunotherapy more effective, it does not explicitly state the FDA approval of pembrolizumab for TMB-high (≥10 mut/Mb) solid tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend asking their oncology team about testing for eligibility for immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends genetic testing (including MSI and TMB) as a crucial step and advises discussing options with the oncologist, which aligns with assessing eligibility for immunotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should consult with their oncologist on the potential next steps.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly advises discussing with his oncology team as soon as possible and to reach out to the medical team urgently for a personalized plan, clearly directing consultation with the oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the oncologist may suggest alternative standard of care therapies.
criterion_scores.justification: It details second-line standard regimens (e.g., nanoliposomal irinotecan + 5-FU/LV, gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel, FOLFOX) and other accepted modalities (radiation for symptoms), indicating alternative standard therapies after progression.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the oncologist may suggest clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: There is a dedicated section on considering clinical trials, including how to find them and discussing eligibility with the oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that re-biopsy of the disease could reveal targetable mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends repeat imaging and 'possibly a biopsy' to assess the cancer’s biology and separately emphasizes tumor profiling/NGS to identify actionable mutations, which together convey that re-biopsy could reveal targetable mutations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend supportive care and symptom management.
criterion_scores.justification: It includes a comprehensive section on palliative/supportive care, symptom management (pain control, nutrition, enzyme supplements, nerve blocks), and hospice consideration, meeting the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there is no approved CAR-T cell therapy for pancreatic cancer at this time.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states: 'At this time, CAR-T therapy is not a standard or FDA-approved treatment for pancreatic cancer,' directly addressing the lack of approval.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe CAR-T cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides an accurate description of CAR-T: collection of patient T-cells, genetic engineering to express chimeric antigen receptors, reinfusion to target cancer cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CAR-T cells are being studied in clinical trials for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes CAR-T is 'being actively researched for pancreatic cancer through clinical trials' and provides examples of targets and how to find trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CAR-T cells are approved for the treatment of other types of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States CAR-T is FDA-approved for certain blood cancers (e.g., leukemias and lymphomas), which is accurate.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that hospice is considered when the medical team estimates a life expectancy of 6 months or less.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states eligibility as an estimated life expectancy of 6 months or less in two places: coverage criteria and under 'Prognosis' (e.g., 'Doctors estimate a life expectancy of 6 months or less').

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the aim of hospice is to maximize quality of life and focus on addressing symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines hospice as focusing on comfort, dignity, and quality of life with emphasis on pain relief and symptom management.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that hospice can take place in the home, a nursing home, or in a dedicated hospice facility.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists care settings including home, nursing home, hospital, and dedicated hospice facility, covering all required locations.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should start with an expression of sympathy and support.
criterion_scores.justification: Opens with 'I'm truly sorry to hear about your father's diagnosis,' which is a clear expression of sympathy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define hospice care.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a clear definition: specialized care for terminal illness focusing on comfort rather than cure, emphasizing end-of-life support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what hospice care covers, including emotional and spiritual support.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a section on 'Emotional and Spiritual Support' detailing counseling, grief/anxiety support, and spiritual care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what hospice care covers, including bereavement support.
criterion_scores.justification: States that hospice provides bereavement counseling for up to a year after the patient's passing under 'Family Support.'

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that fatigue is a common side effect of chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states, 'Fatigue is one of the most common and challenging side effects of chemo.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing symptoms with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises consulting the oncologist/healthcare team for tailored recommendations and provides red-flag situations warranting immediate contact.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that optimizing nutrition and hydration can help manage fatigue.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides detailed guidance on nutrient-rich foods, small frequent meals, supplements as indicated, and hydration goals.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend good sleep hygiene.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes specific sleep hygiene strategies (consistent routine, avoiding screens, optimizing sleep environment) and guidance on naps.

criterion_scores.description: The response should discuss potential causes for fatigue, including the effect of the cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple causes including chemotherapy, anemia, nutritional deficiencies, pain, emotional stress, and the cancer itself.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that light physical activity can improve fatigue.
criterion_scores.justification: States that light activity can boost energy and gives examples (short walks, yoga, tai chi) with safety caveats.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend medication review.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions possible medications to manage fatigue and related symptoms, it does not recommend reviewing current medications for fatigue-inducing effects or interactions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that alternative treatments like cannabis oil have not been proven to help patients with pancreatic cancer live longer or cure them.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states there is no strong evidence from randomized controlled trials that cannabis oil cures or significantly extends life in pancreatic cancer and emphasizes alternatives are not proven to cure or replace standard therapies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cannabis oil is sometimes used to manage cancer-related symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly notes cannabis products may help with pain, nausea/vomiting, appetite loss, anxiety, insomnia, and depression, and references FDA-approved synthetic THC for symptom control.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing the use of cannabis oil with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: A dedicated section advises talking to the oncologist to assess safety, recommend dosing/forms, and monitor interactions or side effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe cannabis oil.
criterion_scores.justification: It defines cannabis oil, distinguishes CBD and THC, discusses psychoactivity, mentions forms (oils, edibles, tinctures), and common alternative names.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cannabis oil is not used as an anti-cancer treatment per guidelines.
criterion_scores.justification: It references ACS and NCI and states cannabis is not a substitute for proven treatments and should be integrated, not replace standard care, aligning with guideline-based positions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe risks of using cannabis oil, including drug interactions.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly warns cannabis can affect hepatic metabolism of other drugs, potentially reducing chemotherapy effectiveness or increasing toxicity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe risks of using cannabis oil, including side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Side effects listed include dizziness, dry mouth, appetite and mood changes, hallucinations, paranoia, and dependence.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe risks of using cannabis oil, including variation in quality.
criterion_scores.justification: It highlights lack of regulation, variability in quality, purity, and dosage, and possible contaminants like pesticides and heavy metals.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe risks of using cannabis oil, including legal concerns.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes legality varies by location, distinguishes CBD vs THC status in the U.S., and mentions medical cannabis program access.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that lack of appetite is a common side effect of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes appetite loss is a common issue for cancer patients and discusses it specifically in the context of the husband’s pancreatic cancer, effectively conveying that it is common.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient should consult with their oncologist, who may refer them to a registered dietitian, oncology nutritionist, and/or palliative care physician to address symptoms and optimize supportive care.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends consulting the oncologist, a registered dietitian specializing in oncology, and a palliative care specialist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme replacement can be pursued.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (e.g., pancrelipase/PERT).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient can try smaller meals.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends small meals, suggesting 5–6 small meals/snacks per day.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient can try more frequent meals.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically advises 5–6 small, frequent meals/snacks throughout the day.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient can try nutritional replacement shakes.
criterion_scores.justification: Suggests smoothies, milkshakes, protein shakes, and commercial supplements like Ensure or Boost.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that appetite stimulants can also be considered.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions that the healthcare team may suggest appetite stimulants if appropriate.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that cancer itself can cause loss of appetite.
criterion_scores.justification: States that factors include the cancer itself as a cause of appetite loss.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that chemotherapy can cause nausea and loss of appetite.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies chemotherapy as a treatment that can contribute to appetite loss and discusses nausea management.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that bloating can decrease appetite.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention bloating as a contributor to decreased appetite.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that pancreatic enzyme deficiency can cause decreased appetite.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of pancreatic enzyme insufficiency or its impact on appetite.

criterion_scores.description: State that they can start with their primary doctor who can help refer to the most local community hospital with oncology services.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises starting with the local healthcare team and explicitly says to get a referral from the primary care doctor to the nearest oncology center/community hospital.

criterion_scores.description: State that if they are able to travel, then major cancer centers offer consultations which can also be done as telehealth.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses traveling to high-volume cancer centers and separately emphasizes that many top centers offer virtual/telehealth consultations.

criterion_scores.description: State that patients can search for NCI-designated cancer centers to find the closest one to them, and explicitly mention that both oncologists and palliative care teams often offer virtual visits through telemedicine or telehealth consultations.
criterion_scores.justification: It provides the NCI cancer center finder link for locating centers and explicitly notes telehealth availability for oncologists and that palliative care can be provided via telehealth.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly recommend reaching out to regional cancer centers, including examples or resources for finding such centers.
criterion_scores.justification: The response recommends high-volume/regional centers, names specific examples (Mayo, MD Anderson, MSK, Johns Hopkins), and provides the NCI center finder resource.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that specialists will often partner with local oncologists to coordinate care.
criterion_scores.justification: While it notes that local oncologists can coordinate basic care and that specialists can provide telehealth input, it does not explicitly state that specialists will partner with local oncologists to coordinate care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should offer sympathy for the stressful situation dealing with insurance coverage.
criterion_scores.justification: Opens with empathy: expresses sorrow about the father's diagnosis and acknowledges the stress of insurance denials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they can work with the hospital’s financial counselor or social worker.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends using hospital social workers and financial counselors to assist with appeals and resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state the person should work with their oncology team to help with the denial.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises obtaining a letter of medical necessity from the oncologist and discussing urgent/bridging options with the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include contacting the insurance company to understand the reason for denial.
criterion_scores.justification: Instructs to review the insurer’s denial letter for reasons and outlines initiating the insurer’s internal appeal process (contact by phone/online/mail), which serves to clarify the denial basis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state one option for remedy is filing an appeal.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly details both internal and external (independent) appeals, including expedited appeals, and provides practical steps and expectations.

criterion_scores.description: Define high-volume centers as those performing at least 40 or 50 Whipple procedures per year.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states high-volume centers perform 20–50+ Whipple procedures and explicitly notes that some experts define this as 40+, which meets the ≥40–50 definition.

criterion_scores.description: State that high-volume centers have significantly lower mortality rates and higher overall survival rates.
criterion_scores.justification: It specifies markedly lower in-hospital mortality (2–4% vs. 10–15%) and notes better overall survival at high-volume centers.

criterion_scores.description: State that high-volume centers have significantly lower complication rates.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly says high-volume centers have fewer complications such as infections, leaks, and bleeding.

criterion_scores.description: State that at a high-volume center, the surgeon is more likely to be a specialist in pancreas surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes surgeons at high-volume centers are often fellowship-trained specialists focusing on pancreatic/GI cancers and perform these operations frequently.

criterion_scores.description: State that high-volume centers often have access to clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states high-volume centers often participate in clinical trials, offering access to cutting-edge treatments.

criterion_scores.description: State that high-volume centers have access to the latest treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions access to cutting-edge treatments and advanced tools such as robotic-assisted surgery and intraoperative imaging.

criterion_scores.description: State disadvantages of going to a high-volume center, including travel time.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses the burden of travel to high-volume centers, sometimes out-of-state, compared with local proximity.

criterion_scores.description: State disadvantages of going to a high-volume center, including more complicated logistics.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes logistical challenges (lodging, coordination, patient navigators) and contrasts them with the convenience of local care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network as a resource for financial assistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN), describes Patient Central, grants, and provides contact info (phone and website), framing it as a starting point for financial resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention CancerCare as a resource for financial assistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists CancerCare and states it offers limited financial grants for co-pays, transportation, and home care, with contact info, meeting the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the American Cancer Society as a resource for financial assistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes the American Cancer Society (ACS), noting financial assistance programs such as Hope Lodge, transportation, and some medical costs, with contact details.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing financial concerns with a social worker.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises connecting with "Hospital Social Workers and Financial Navigators" to help with financial planning and applying for aid.

criterion_scores.description: The response should offer sympathy for the stressful situation dealing with financial burden during cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Begins with empathetic language: "I'm so sorry to hear about your loved one's pancreatic cancer diagnosis—this is an incredibly challenging time, and the financial aspects can add significant stress."

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing financial concerns with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: States, "Ask your oncologist for a referral" to social workers/financial navigators, indicating engagement of the oncology team for financial concerns.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing financial concerns with a financial counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends: "Seek Professional Advice: A financial counselor or patient advocate can help maximize benefits and minimize out-of-pocket costs."

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that depression is common among patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states depression is common and provides a prevalence range (33–70%) for pancreatic cancer patients.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing the patient’s mood with their oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises to start with the oncologist, mentions screening tools (e.g., PHQ-9), and coordinating care.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions support groups as helpful for patients with cancer experiencing depression.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends support groups and names PanCAN, ACS, and CancerCare.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions seeking immediate evaluation by a medical professional if the patient is experiencing thoughts of harming themself or others.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises immediate contact with the doctor or crisis resources if suicidal thoughts are present.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers the emergency department and calling 988 if the patient experiences thoughts of harming themself or others.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides 988 but does not explicitly mention going to the emergency department.

criterion_scores.description: The response points to published scientific studies describing the prevalence of depression in pancreatic cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Cites studies and sources (e.g., The Lancet Oncology, NCCN, 2020 review in Supportive Care in Cancer) in support of prevalence data.

criterion_scores.description: The response reviews the signs and symptoms of depression.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists persistent low mood, anhedonia, sleep/appetite changes, irritability, and self-harm thoughts.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing the patient’s mood with a mental health professional.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends referral to a psychiatrist, psychologist, or oncology social worker.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that there are various treatment options for depression.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes multiple treatments including medication, therapy, and integrative approaches.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that there are both pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic treatment options for depression.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions SSRIs (pharmacologic) and CBT, mindfulness, counseling (non-pharmacologic).

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions lifestyle changes that support improvements in mental health.
criterion_scores.justification: Suggests light physical activity, nutrition focus, sleep hygiene, and relaxation techniques.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that based on the ASCO guidelines, optimal care of depression should follow a stepped-care model.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention ASCO guidelines or a stepped-care model.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), behavior therapy (BT), and behavioral activation (BA) are the most effective treatments for managing depressive symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions CBT but not BT/BA nor that these are the most effective per ASCO.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that exercise both during and after treatment can significantly reduce depression.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages light physical activity but does not state the ASCO-based finding that exercise during and after treatment significantly reduces depression.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that pharmacotherapy is not recommended as a first-line treatment for depression.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends SSRIs without noting that pharmacotherapy is not first-line per ASCO.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises: 'Talk to Your Doctor... Share these questions with your oncologist' and notes the care team provides personalized insights.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that many aspects of a patient’s health impact their prognosis.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple factors including age, overall health, tumor genetics, treatment response, lifestyle/support, and comorbidities affecting prognosis.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines overall survival as it is used in clinical research.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines overall survival as the percentage alive after a certain time from diagnosis regardless of cause of death, which aligns with OS concept for lay readers.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines progression-free survival as it is used in clinical research.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains PFS (grouped with DFS) as time without cancer returning or worsening, capturing the core idea of time until progression/recurrence.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that overall survival and progression-free survival are typically reported as medians.
criterion_scores.justification: Although 'median survival' is defined and examples are given, the response does not explicitly state that OS and PFS are typically reported as median times in studies.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains the above biostatistics terms (overall survival, progression-free survival, and median) in laymen’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides clear, plain-language definitions for overall survival, relative survival, progression-free survival, and median survival.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that survival data is best reported in terms of the stage of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States statistics are grouped by stage and provides stage-specific survival rates, noting resectability and type differences.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the limitations of applying reported statistics to patients’ individual cases.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes that statistics are averages from past cohorts, not predictions; acknowledges variability by individual factors and evolving treatments.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the difference between overall survival and progression-free survival.
criterion_scores.justification: Differentiates OS (alive regardless of cause of death) from PFS (time without return/worsening), making the distinction clear.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that survival is influenced by tumor characteristics such as genetic mutations (BRCA, KRAS), size, and location.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically references size, location, operability, and genetic mutations (KRAS, BRCA) as prognostic factors.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that survival depends on treatments received (chemotherapy, surgery, targeted therapy, no treatment, etc.) and treatment response.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, targeted drugs, immunotherapy, and treatment response significantly influence outcomes; provides examples.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that new treatments and advancements are being developed all the time, and these could potentially improve outcomes in the future.
criterion_scores.justification: States that statistics may not reflect recent advances, mentions improving survival, personalized/targeted therapies, immunotherapy, and clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises that the oncology team can provide tailored details and explicitly suggests asking the doctors specific questions in the 'Next Steps' section.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that a liquid biopsy is a blood test.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states that a liquid biopsy analyzes a sample of blood and compares it to traditional tissue biopsies.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that liquid biopsies involve analyzing circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) from blood samples.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly defines ctDNA as bits of genetic material from cancer cells and describes analysis using techniques such as next-generation sequencing.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains there are many different tests which evaluate various things including circulating tumor DNA, circulating tumor cells, and proteins in the blood.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists ctDNA, circulating tumor cells (CTCs), and other biomarkers such as proteins, exosomes, and RNA.

criterion_scores.description: The response says that liquid biopsies do not replace tissue biopsies in the diagnosis of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It states liquid biopsies are not a replacement for all traditional biopsies and can complement them.

criterion_scores.description: The response says the results of liquid biopsies must be interpreted by a medical professional.
criterion_scores.justification: While it suggests discussing with doctors, it does not explicitly state that liquid biopsy results must be interpreted by a medical professional.

criterion_scores.description: The response says the results of liquid biopsies may be helpful when combined with imaging and pathology results.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes results are often used alongside imaging (CT scans) or tissue biopsies, indicating combination with imaging and pathology.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions there are liquid biopsies in various stages of development for different kinds of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions FDA approvals for some cancers like lung and breast, and investigational/off-label use for pancreas, indicating varying stages across cancers.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the limitations of liquid biopsies, including sensitivity, false positives, and cost.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses sensitivity limitations, possible false positives/negatives, and variability in availability and cost.

criterion_scores.description: The response says there are currently no FDA approved liquid biopsies for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It states FDA approvals exist for some cancers (e.g., lung/breast) but for pancreas they are often investigational/off-label, implying no FDA-approved pancreatic indication.

criterion_scores.description: The response says health insurance may not pay for these tests.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly notes that insurance coverage varies, indicating possible non-coverage.

criterion_scores.description: The response says liquid biopsies may be able to identify genetic mutations present in the cancer which can help to guide treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes identifying mutations like KRAS or BRCA and using that information to guide targeted therapies (e.g., PARP inhibitors).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that liquid biopsies are noninvasive and can expedite testing because there is no need to retrieve archival blocks or arrange for a new biopsy.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it mentions noninvasiveness and avoiding repeated surgeries, it does not specifically state expediting testing by avoiding retrieval of archival blocks or arranging a new biopsy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that copy-number changes may be more difficult to assess in cfDNA, and fusion testing may be more limited in common cfDNA tests currently used.
criterion_scores.justification: It does not address limitations specific to detecting copy-number changes or gene fusions in cfDNA assays.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that this is still under active research and not yet standard of care for all cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes liquid biopsies as an emerging tool, notes research stage and investigational use in pancreatic cancer, implying it is not standard of care for all patients.

criterion_scores.description: The response considers the costs of travel.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly factors in travel costs under Financial Considerations (includes travel, accommodations, and hidden fees).

criterion_scores.description: The response considers the costs of healthcare abroad.
criterion_scores.justification: Details treatment-related costs (surgery, hospital stay, medications, follow-up), gives estimated ranges, and advises obtaining detailed quotes.

criterion_scores.description: The response considers logistics of travel, including the need for passports and/or visas.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses medical visas and entry requirements (e.g., India’s M-visa, Thailand’s medical tourist visa) and related documentation.

criterion_scores.description: The response considers language and cultural barriers.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses language access (English-speaking staff, translators) and cultural differences in care.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that patients receiving treatment for pancreatic cancer often require significant support from their family and friends.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes the need for companions/family support and references counseling and advocacy groups.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends considering if the patient is medically safe for travel.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises medical clearance, ‘fit to fly’ certificate, consideration of symptoms/complications (e.g., clots, infections), and emergency preparedness.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends researching the quality of healthcare in the intended destination.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends high-volume centers, cites specific hospitals, emphasizes accreditation (JCI/ESMO), outcomes, and patient reviews.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing all travel plans with a medical professional prior to leaving.
criterion_scores.justification: Urges consultation with the oncologist and healthcare team, and obtaining clearance prior to travel.

criterion_scores.description: The response says that delaying the start of treatment for pancreatic cancer can be harmful.
criterion_scores.justification: States treatments often need to start quickly and to factor in travel time, implying delay can be detrimental.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends researching pancreatic cancer outcomes in the intended destination as compared to her home country.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises reviewing success/survival statistics and comparing offerings abroad to local options.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends understanding the patient’s treatment options, including clinical trials, which may be available in her home country before making travel plans.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions confirming availability of desired treatments and considering local clinical trials with resources like ClinicalTrials.gov.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention considerations related to insurance funding.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses health insurance coverage for international care, medical travel insurance, and potential funding sources.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to consider local accommodations when traveling abroad for treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifies planning lodging near the hospital (e.g., serviced apartments) and transportation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to consider challenges with follow-up care when traveling abroad for treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Highlights need for post-treatment monitoring plans, return vs. stay decisions, and transfer of records/coordinating with local doctors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that immunizations and infection prevention are important, especially for immunosuppressed patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not advise on immunizations or specific infection-prevention measures for immunosuppressed patients; only general references to infections/pandemics.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that telemedicine and remote support can be leveraged for follow-up, symptom management, and multidisciplinary care, reducing the need for frequent travel and facilitating access to expertise at high-volume centers.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions telemedicine for second opinions and as an alternative to travel, but does not specify its use for follow-up, symptom management, or multidisciplinary care.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that bowel changes, including diarrhea, nausea, and constipation, are common among patients undergoing treatment for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States that treatments often affect the bowels and explicitly lists diarrhea, constipation, and nausea as common side effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that chemotherapy, radiation therapy, surgery, and other treatments such as pain medications can impact the bowels.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly discusses chemotherapy, radiation, surgery (Whipple), and pain medications (opioids) causing bowel changes.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that bowel changes can also be due to infections.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists infections as a possible cause of bowel changes.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing specific concerns with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises contacting their doctor promptly and specifically mentions the oncologist as part of the care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends keeping a log of events related to food intake, fluid intake, and bowel symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends tracking bowel symptoms but does not explicitly include logging food or fluid intake.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing the above log with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: States that the symptom log will help the doctor pinpoint the issue, implying discussion with the care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends if the patient has not had a bowel movement in more than 24 hours and is not passing gas, their bowels may be obstructed, which is a medical emergency and requires immediate evaluation in an emergency department.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions blockages needing urgent attention but does not provide the specific 24-hour/no gas guidance or explicitly recommend immediate ED evaluation.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends if the patient is nauseous and unable to keep any food or drink down without vomiting, this can quickly lead to severe dehydration, which requires urgent evaluation by a medical professional and potentially intravenous fluids and medicines.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly advise urgent evaluation and possible IV fluids if unable to keep food or liquids down.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends if the patient is experiencing severe abdominal pain, this may represent a medical emergency which requires immediate evaluation in an emergency department.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not provide emergency guidance for severe abdominal pain.

criterion_scores.description: The response says patients with pancreatic cancer may experience pancreatic insufficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes enzyme deficiency due to cancer/surgery and need for enzymes, which conveys pancreatic exocrine insufficiency.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains pancreatic insufficiency is related to a deficiency in the pancreatic enzymes which break down food and can cause diarrhea and bloating.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains reduced enzyme production leading to maldigestion with diarrhea (steatorrhea), bloating, and gas.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains there are supplementary pancreatic enzymes that can be taken to alleviate the symptoms of pancreatic insufficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions pancreatic enzyme supplements (e.g., Creon) to manage malabsorption.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains if the bowel changes are due to chemotherapy, the treating oncologist can often prescribe additional medications to control these side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions medications like loperamide or laxatives but does not state that the oncologist can prescribe additional medications specifically for chemo-related side effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response says proper nutrition is an important part of cancer care outcomes.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages small, frequent meals but does not explicitly state the importance of nutrition for cancer care outcomes.

criterion_scores.description: The response says it is important to remain hydrated.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises staying hydrated and increasing fluids.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that it is important to determine the cause of the bowel changes to manage them effectively.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes discussing with the care team for accurate assessment and determining the cause via tests.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that gastric outlet/duodenal obstruction can occur in up to 10% of patients with pancreatic cancer, leading to symptoms like early satiety, nausea, postprandial vomiting, and weight loss.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention gastric outlet/duodenal obstruction or the 10% statistic or the specific symptom cluster.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that patients with malignant ascites from pancreatic cancer may experience abdominal discomfort, nausea, and vomiting.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention malignant ascites or its symptoms.
