criterion_scores.description: The response should state types of surgical procedures used in pancreatic cancer and describe distal pancreatectomy.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes distal pancreatectomy as removal of the body/tail and often spleen for tumors in those areas.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state types of surgical procedures used in pancreatic cancer and describe total pancreatectomy.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions total pancreatectomy, removal of the entire pancreas, and the consequence of diabetes/digestive issues.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that surgical resection is the only potentially curative option for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Says surgery offers the best chance and can potentially cure but does not state it is the only potentially curative option.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that deciding on surgery requires multidisciplinary evaluation and mention anatomical, biological, or patient factors.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises multidisciplinary team review and discusses anatomical (major blood vessels, location), biological (spread), and patient factors (age, overall health).

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing the case with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly recommends discussing options with her oncology team and seeking a specialist second opinion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the stage of the cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response links treatment with stage: “Stages and Treatment: Staging determines the extent (e.g., localized, regional, or metastatic). Treatments may include…,” implying treatment decisions are stage-dependent.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the location of the cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention that anatomic location within the pancreas (e.g., head vs body/tail) affects treatment decisions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that treatment of pancreatic cancer is multimodality and includes surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists multiple modalities and includes surgery: “Treatments may include surgery (e.g., Whipple procedure…), chemotherapy, radiation…,” satisfying multimodality including surgery.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that treatment of pancreatic cancer is multimodality and includes chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Chemotherapy is explicitly included among treatment modalities.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that treatment of pancreatic cancer is multimodality and includes radiation.
criterion_scores.justification: Radiation is explicitly listed as a treatment modality.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that early, multidisciplinary management is essential to optimize outcomes.
criterion_scores.justification: While it recommends a multidisciplinary team and early palliative care, it does not state that early multidisciplinary management is essential to optimize outcomes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that care is best coordinated at high-volume centers with expertise in pancreatic malignancies.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises second opinions at high-volume centers and notes better outcomes: “ensure it's at a center with experienced surgeons (outcomes are better at high-volume facilities).”

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that symptom management is an important part of the care of patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It emphasizes symptom control via palliative care and suggests asking about managing symptoms/pain.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the basics of pancreatic cancer, including that the most common type is pancreatic adenocarcinoma.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states, “The most common is pancreatic adenocarcinoma (about 95% of cases).”

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how pancreatic cancer is staged based on the NCCN guidelines (version 2.2025) TNM staging and AJCC prognostic groups.
criterion_scores.justification: Only general staging terms (localized, regional, metastatic) are provided; no TNM detail or AJCC stage group descriptions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that pancreatic cancer is an aggressive malignancy with a poor prognosis, often presenting at an advanced stage.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes late presentation and poor survival: “often doesn't show symptoms until it's advanced” and “overall 5-year survival rate is around 10–12%.”

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend writing down questions in advance to ensure that all concerns are addressed during consultations.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicit recommendation: “Write down questions in advance,” with example questions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that advocacy for comprehensive testing is important, including somatic and germline genetic testing.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises genetic testing (e.g., BRCA—germline) and references PanCAN’s “Know Your Tumor” program for personalized testing (tumor molecular/somatic profiling), covering both.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to inquire about clinical trial opportunities, as participation may provide access to novel therapies.
criterion_scores.justification: Clinical trials are recommended in questions and resources, with guidance to search trial databases.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that cancer.net and the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (pancan.org) provide high-quality information, support services, and advocacy opportunities.
criterion_scores.justification: PanCAN is highlighted, but cancer.net is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the user discuss this case with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends consulting healthcare professionals and explicitly includes an oncologist in the multidisciplinary team; also suggests second opinions at expert centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (pNETs) are usually sporadic.
criterion_scores.justification: States that most PNETs (about 80–90%) are sporadic.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (pNETs) do tend to have a genetic component in a significant minority of cases.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that around 10–20% are associated with hereditary syndromes, indicating a significant minority.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that some cases of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (pNETs) are associated with hereditary syndromes.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that a portion of PNETs are linked to hereditary syndromes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1).
criterion_scores.justification: MEN1 is named, described, and contextualized as the most common syndrome associated with PNETs.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL).
criterion_scores.justification: VHL is named, its gene is identified, and association with PNETs is described.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).
criterion_scores.justification: NF1 is explicitly mentioned as a less common associated syndrome.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC).
criterion_scores.justification: TSC (TSC1/TSC2) is named and its association with PNETs is noted.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that genetic testing is available for pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states that germline and somatic (tumor) genetic testing are available and describes processes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that they have concerns about the risk of cancer, they should talk with a genetic counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends consultation with a genetic counselor and provides resource (NSGC).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that approximately 10–17% of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (pNETs) are associated with inherited syndromes.
criterion_scores.justification: States that 10–20% are hereditary; while slightly broader, it conveys the approximate magnitude consistent with the 10–17% range.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that these inherited syndromes often present at a younger age.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes hereditary cases tend to be diagnosed earlier, often before age 50.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that germline mutations are also found in sporadic-appearing pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (pNETs), including mutations in DNA repair genes such as MUTYH, CHEK2, and BRCA2, as well as MEN1 and VHL.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention germline findings in sporadic-appearing cases or DNA repair genes (MUTYH, CHEK2, BRCA2); discusses somatic tumor mutations instead.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that multigene panel testing is recommended, as it can identify both syndromic and non-syndromic germline variants relevant for familial risk assessment.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions panels for hereditary syndromes but does not recommend multigene panel testing to capture both syndromic and non-syndromic germline variants.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the user discuss this case with a medical professional.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly advises consulting a healthcare professional (oncologist, genetic counselor) and reiterates this in the next steps.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN) as a source for survivor stories.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly references PanCAN, notes a 'Survivor Stories' section, and provides the helpline (877-2-PANCAN).

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends asking the oncology team for additional support group recommendations.
criterion_scores.justification: While it suggests joining support groups and discussing clinical trials with an oncologist, it does not explicitly recommend asking the oncology team for support group recommendations.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions Cancer Support Community (CSC) as a resource for support or survivor stories.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions 'Cancer Support Community' directly and references Gilda’s Club/Cancer Support Community for groups.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions Let’s Win! Pancreatic Cancer survivor stories.
criterion_scores.justification: Let’s Win! Pancreatic Cancer is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the American Society of Clinical Oncology’s patient-facing website (www.cancer.net) as a source for stories of hope.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically cites Cancer.Net (ASCO) and its 'Personal Stories' area.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that organizations provide patient and survivor stories, peer support networks, and opportunities to connect with others who have faced similar diagnoses.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes PanCAN survivor stories and its one-on-one network, ACS forums, and Inspire groups—clearly indicating stories, peer networks, and ways to connect.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that peer support and shared experiences are recognized as powerful tools for maintaining motivation and a sense of hope during the cancer journey.
criterion_scores.justification: States that hearing from others provides strength and that sharing/hearing stories can be 'incredibly empowering,' supporting hope and motivation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define stage IV pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states stage IV pancreatic cancer "has spread to distant organs," which is a correct definition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that the disease is not curable.
criterion_scores.justification: States the goal is to extend life and manage symptoms "rather than aiming for a cure," clearly conveying that it is not curable.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include the goal of treatment is to control the cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions extending life and shrinking tumors, it does not explicitly state that a treatment goal is to control the cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include the goal of treatment to improve symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Repeatedly emphasizes symptom management and relief (e.g., pain, nausea, digestive issues), meeting the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the cornerstone of treatment for stage IV pancreatic cancer is systemic chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: States chemotherapy is "often the mainstay for stage IV," which aligns with chemotherapy being the cornerstone.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include chemotherapy regimens listed in NCCN guidelines (version 2.2025) for treatment of metastatic pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists FOLFIRINOX and gemcitabine plus nab-paclitaxel, both NCCN-recommended regimens for metastatic disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should discuss that clinical trials are another option.
criterion_scores.justification: Thoroughly discusses clinical trials and provides specific resources (ClinicalTrials.gov, PanCAN, NCI).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there may be targeted treatments based on genetic mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes targeted options like olaparib for BRCA mutations and larotrectinib for NTRK fusions; also mentions pembrolizumab for MSI-H.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the tumor have genetic testing.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends early genetic testing (including tumor/l liquid biopsy) to guide treatment and assess hereditary risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that early palliative care referral is recommended at diagnosis to optimize symptom management, psychological support, and advance care planning.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises palliative/supportive care can start alongside active treatment and discusses advance care planning, aligning with early referral principles.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that aggressive symptom management, such as management of pain, fatigue, nausea, and gastrointestinal symptoms is essential.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions comprehensive symptom management including pain, nausea, fatigue, weight loss, and digestive problems.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy should be considered for exocrine insufficiency, and nutritional support is important for maintaining weight and strength.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends pancreatic enzyme supplements (e.g., Creon) and provides detailed nutritional strategies to maintain weight and strength.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that psychosocial support, including counseling and peer support, is critical for both patients and families.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses counseling, support groups, caregiver support, and stress management resources for patients and families.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the user discuss this case with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly advises discussing options with the oncology team and suggests second opinions at major cancer centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that management of pancreatic tumors involves a multidisciplinary team of surgeons, medical oncologists, and radiation oncologists.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that pancreatic cancer requires a multidisciplinary team, including surgical oncologists, medical oncologists, and radiation oncologists.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that outcomes are significantly improved when care is delivered by a multidisciplinary team at high-volume centers.
criterion_scores.justification: The response links better outcomes to high-volume experience (e.g., surgeons performing many Whipple procedures have better outcomes) and emphasizes care at academic/high-volume hospitals with multidisciplinary teams, satisfying the intent of improved outcomes at high-volume multidisciplinary centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide information for the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN).
criterion_scores.justification: PanCAN is named with actionable details, including the helpline (877-573-9971) and website (pancan.org), and mentions Patient Central.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide information for the American Cancer Society (ACS).
criterion_scores.justification: The American Cancer Society is included with its website (cancer.org) and a description of available support.

criterion_scores.description: The recommendation should provide a link to the NCI website for finding an NCI-designated cancer center.
criterion_scores.justification: The response provides the NCI link to find centers: cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care/find-center.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that high-volume centers—defined as institutions performing at least 15 pancreatic resections annually—demonstrate superior survival rates, lower postoperative morbidity, improved lymphadenectomy, shorter hospital stays, and better access to adjuvant therapies.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions that high-volume surgeons have better outcomes, it does not define high-volume centers as ≥15 resections/year nor enumerate the specified advantages (survival, morbidity, lymphadenectomy quality, hospital stay, adjuvant therapy access).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that high-volume centers are typically academic medical centers, National Cancer Institute-designated cancer centers, or hospitals with established pancreatic cancer programs.
criterion_scores.justification: The response directs users to NCI-Designated Cancer Centers and notes that top doctors are often at academic or high-volume hospitals with multidisciplinary teams, aligning with the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to request referrals from local oncologists or primary care providers, who can direct patients to high-volume centers and experienced teams.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises asking the primary care physician and oncologist for referrals and emphasizes the role of current providers in guiding to specialists.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the user discuss this case with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends seeking second opinions from a specialist and specifically mentions engaging the oncologist, effectively advising discussion with an oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that some chemotherapy can have negative effects on the heart.
criterion_scores.justification: States: 'certain treatments for pancreatic cancer (like chemotherapy) can sometimes cause cardiotoxicity.'

criterion_scores.description: The response specifically mentions that 5-fluorouracil (or “5-FU”) can harm the heart.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions '5-fluorouracil (5-FU, often part of FOLFIRINOX)' as a drug that can cause heart issues.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends monitoring for shortness of breath.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'Shortness of breath' under symptoms to watch for and to report.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends monitoring for chest pain.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'Chest pain or discomfort' and advises to report urgently if severe.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends monitoring for fast heart rate.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'Palpitations or irregular heartbeat' and describes 'feeling like the heart is racing.'

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends monitoring for dizziness.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'Dizziness or fainting' among symptoms to watch.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends monitoring for unusual fatigue.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'Fatigue or weakness: Unusual tiredness' as a symptom to monitor.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends discussing any new symptom with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises to 'report any new or worsening symptoms immediately to her doctor' and elsewhere to 'please discuss this with her oncologist.'

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends discussing any concerning symptom with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises to report 'new or worsening symptoms immediately to her doctor' and to seek emergency care for severe chest pain; also instructs to talk to her oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that electrocardiograms can be used to monitor the heart.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions baseline 'electrocardiogram (ECG/EKG)' and 'Regular ECGs' during treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that echocardiogram can be used to monitor heart function.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends baseline echocardiogram and repeat echocardiograms every few months to monitor ejection fraction.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that blood pressure can be used to monitor the heart.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises 'Blood pressure checks at every visit, as hypertension can worsen heart risks.'

criterion_scores.description: The response specifically mentions that capecitabine can harm the heart.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'capecitabine' among drugs that can cause heart issues.

criterion_scores.description: The response specifically mentions that some targeted therapies can harm the heart.
criterion_scores.justification: States targeted therapies (e.g., erlotinib) 'typically have minimal cardiac impact' and does not state that some can harm the heart.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that pancreatic cancer treatments can cause at least three cardiac issues: heart failure, arrhythmias, hypertension, ischemia, or cardiomyopathy.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias, coronary artery spasm/ischemia, and heart failure as potential effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that the risk of cardiac side effects is higher in patients with preexisting cardiovascular conditions or those receiving specific agents such as anthracyclines or fluoropyrimidines.
criterion_scores.justification: States monitoring is important 'particularly if she has pre-existing heart conditions...' and discusses fluoropyrimidines (5-FU, capecitabine) as higher-risk agents.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends baseline cardiac risk assessment and regular monitoring with echocardiography, cardiac biomarkers, and clinical evaluation for early/asymptomatic cardiac dysfunction.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends baseline ECG, echocardiogram, and cardiac biomarkers (troponin/BNP), plus ongoing ECGs, echocardiograms, BP checks; emphasizes early detection.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly references recommendations from the ACC and/or ASCO that pretherapy evaluation and ongoing surveillance are recommended for patients with cardiovascular risk factors or those receiving cardiotoxic agents.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions 'Guidelines from organizations like ASCO recommend tailored cardio-oncology surveillance' but does not explicitly state ACC/ASCO recommend pretherapy evaluation and ongoing surveillance for patients with risk factors or those receiving cardiotoxic agents.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends that the user discuss the case with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'please discuss this with her oncologist' and 'Talk to Her Oncologist: Share your concerns ASAP.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that treatment decisions are personal decisions.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states stopping treatment is a "deeply personal choice" and emphasizes respecting the individual's decision.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend listening to their feelings.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises to "begin by listening without judgment" and suggests asking about feelings and priorities.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend validating their feelings.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically notes that listening "validates their decision" and emphasizes empathy and nonjudgment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend respecting their autonomy.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly says to support them by "respecting their autonomy" and honoring their right to choose.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend supporting their quality of life.
criterion_scores.justification: Highlights palliative/hospice care focused on comfort, symptom management, meaningful activities, and emotional/spiritual support to improve quality of life.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend offering reassurance.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides empathic language and validation but does not explicitly recommend that the caregiver offer reassurance to the patient (e.g., reassuring ongoing support or non-abandonment).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that clear, compassionate communication about prognosis, treatment options, and goals of care is important.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages open, honest conversations and meeting with the oncologist to discuss disease progression, symptom management, and options, aligning with goals-of-care communication.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that transitioning to hospice care may be appropriate when the focus shifts entirely to comfort and dignity.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains hospice focuses on comfort and is appropriate when life expectancy is limited, making clear the shift to comfort-oriented care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that hospice provides intensive symptom management, psychosocial and spiritual support, and home-based care, while avoiding non-beneficial interventions such as hospitalization or aggressive procedures.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions in-home care, medications, and counseling, but does not state hospice avoids non-beneficial interventions (e.g., hospitalization/aggressive procedures) nor explicitly tie spiritual support to hospice services.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention addressing practical issues related to end-of-life decision-making, such as managing costs and accessing resources.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers advance directives, power of attorney, home modifications, insurance coverage (Medicare for hospice), financial assistance (PanCAN), and resource links, addressing practical and cost/resource issues.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the user discuss this case with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly advises scheduling a meeting with the oncologist to discuss implications of stopping treatment and alternatives.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing legal planning with a qualified professional.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises consulting an attorney specializing in estate planning or elder law, a financial advisor, and the healthcare team to tailor documents.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that laws can vary state to state.
criterion_scores.justification: States that laws vary by state (and country), emphasizing jurisdictional differences.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of an advance healthcare directive or living will.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines an Advance Directive/Living Will and describes specifying life-sustaining treatments, pain management, and organ donation preferences.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of a medical power of attorney.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes a Durable Power of Attorney for Healthcare/Healthcare Proxy and its role in making medical decisions if the patient is incapacitated.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of a durable power of attorney for finances.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains a Durable Power of Attorney for Finances, including managing bills, bank accounts, and investments if the patient cannot, and that it remains effective during incapacity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of a last will and testament.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines a Last Will and Testament, covering asset distribution, executor designation, and guardianship for minors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that POLST forms translate preferences into actionable medical orders for emergency settings.
criterion_scores.justification: States that POLST/MOLST are medical orders translating wishes into actionable instructions for providers, especially in emergencies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that these documents ensure that care aligns with the patient’s values and preferences, especially if the patient loses decision-making capacity due to disease progression or treatment effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that planning ensures his wishes are respected and that healthcare documents ensure his medical wishes are followed if he becomes unable to communicate.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that it is essential to have ongoing, structured conversations about goals of care, as patient preferences may change over time.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages open conversations about his wishes and notes documents can be revised as needed, implying ongoing dialogue as preferences may change.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing their concerns with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises: 'speak with their oncology team; they often have social workers who specialize in financial navigation.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing their concerns with a social worker.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends consulting 'a hospital social worker' and references social workers again in the Next Steps section.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing their concerns with a financial counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'Many hospitals have dedicated financial counselors who can help you apply' and suggests contacting billing/financial aid.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that patient advocacy organizations can help and include information on the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN).
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies PanCAN as a resource, describes services (financial navigation), and provides phone number and website.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that patient advocacy organizations can help and include information on CancerCare.org.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes CancerCare with description of financial assistance and contact information.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that patient advocacy organizations can help and include information for the American Cancer Society.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes ACS with programs (transportation, lodging) and contact info.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that patients with pancreatic cancer who are facing significant medical bills have access to several financial assistance options.
criterion_scores.justification: States there are 'several financial assistance programs' for cancer-related costs in the specific context of pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that financial assistance options include patient assistance programs (PAPs) from independent charity foundations, pharmaceutical company programs, and direct grants from nonprofit organizations.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions PAPs from pharma companies, independent co-pay foundations (HealthWell, PAN), and non-profit grants/resources (ACS, CancerCare).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that these programs may provide co-payment assistance, help with insurance premiums, and sometimes support for non-medical expenses such as transportation or housing.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifies co-pay assistance and premiums (HealthWell), and non-medical support such as transportation and lodging/housing (ACS, CancerCare).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that eligibility is generally based on annual household income (often up to 400–500% of the federal poverty level), insurance status, and physician endorsement.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes eligibility factors like income and insurance status but does not mention 400–500% FPL thresholds or physician endorsement.

criterion_scores.description: Describe PARP inhibitors as targeted agents that block the PARP enzyme involved in repairing single-strand DNA breaks.
criterion_scores.justification: The response identifies PARP inhibitors as targeted cancer therapy that block PARP enzymes involved in DNA repair and explains synthetic lethality. While it does not explicitly say "single-strand DNA breaks," it clearly conveys PARP’s role in DNA repair and enzyme inhibition.

criterion_scores.description: Mention use in advanced pancreatic cancer with a germline BRCA mutation.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states PARP inhibitors are primarily used in patients with germline BRCA1/2 mutations and specifies metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma, meeting the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: State use as maintenance therapy in metastatic pancreatic cancer with germline BRCA1/2 and no progression after at least 16 weeks of first-line platinum-based chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly describes olaparib maintenance for metastatic disease with germline BRCA1/2 after at least 16 weeks of first-line platinum-based chemotherapy and no progression, matching the POLO trial context. Note: It inaccurately implies gemcitabine+nab-paclitaxel includes platinum, but the core requirement is correctly stated.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend comprehensive germline BRCA testing for all pancreatic cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states that doctors often recommend germline testing for all patients with pancreatic cancer and emphasizes its importance for PARP inhibitor eligibility.

criterion_scores.description: Mention ASCO specifically recommends olaparib based on the POLO trial showing PFS benefit without compromising quality of life.
criterion_scores.justification: The response references the POLO trial and PFS benefit but does not mention ASCO’s specific recommendation nor the finding that quality of life was maintained.

criterion_scores.description: State that other PARP inhibitors and combinations are investigational; align with NCCN Guidelines (v2.2025) context for systemic therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes that other PARP inhibitors (e.g., rucaparib) and combinations are being studied and are not standard outside trials, fulfilling the investigational-status requirement. It references NCCN generally, though it does not detail v2.2025 regimens.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend discussing the case with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly advises discussing details with the oncology team and provides specific questions to ask, clearly meeting this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend considering proximity to the treatment center.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises aiming for a center within a 1–2 hour drive and discusses reducing travel fatigue and logistical burden.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend considering housing options near the cancer center.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides short-term and long-term housing options (Hope Lodge, hospital-affiliated housing, renting/buying) and associated considerations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend considering transportation to and from the cancer center.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses commute time, traffic, public transportation, airport access, and mentions ACS Road to Recovery for transportation support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend considering financial considerations.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes treatment costs, relocation and living expenses, cost-of-living comparisons, financial aid resources, and benefits planning.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include insurance coverage.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically discusses insurance coverage (in/out-of-network), and implications for Medicare/Medicaid/employer insurance with relocation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend considering the social support system near the cancer center.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses family impact, caregiver support, support groups, and community resources affecting social support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide information for the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN) Patient services.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides PanCAN contact (877-573-9971, pancan.org) and describes case manager support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide information for the American Cancer Society (ACS) page on finding a doctor.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions ACS resources (Road to Recovery, lodging) but does not reference or link the ACS 'find a doctor' page.

criterion_scores.description: The recommendation should provide a link to the NCI website for finding an NCI-designated cancer center.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes the NCI-designated centers link (cancer.gov/research/infrastructure/cancer-centers).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the NCCN Panel (version 2.2025) recommends that decisions about diagnosis and management involve multidisciplinary teams at high-volume centers with appropriate high-volume imaging studies.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions NCCN generally but does not cite version 2.2025 or state the specific NCCN recommendation regarding multidisciplinary, high-volume centers and imaging.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly mentions patient preferences, goals of care, or quality of life as central to the decision.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes balancing medical outcomes with overall well-being and discusses quality-of-life factors (climate, community, activities).

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly addresses open communication about expectations, prognosis, or the impact of relocation on daily life.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages family discussion and addresses daily living impacts (access to pharmacies, groceries, accessibility).

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly mentions continuity of care, transferring medical records, coordinating with the current care team, or ensuring uninterrupted access to medications/supportive services.
criterion_scores.justification: Contains a 'Continuity of Care' section advising seamless medical record transfer and coordination with the current doctor.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly mentions access to multidisciplinary care and/or clinical trials as important factors.
criterion_scores.justification: Highlights multidisciplinary teams and access to clinical trials as key considerations.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends discussing the case with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises consulting with the mother's oncology team and current doctor for referrals and second opinions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing the anxiety with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly advises talking to the oncologist, nurse, or palliative care specialist about the anxiety.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include considering relaxation techniques prior to the scan.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, guided imagery, mindfulness, and creating a calming pre-scan routine.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend asking the oncology team about what will happen during the scan.
criterion_scores.justification: It includes a section to ask about scan details, covering duration, sensations, preparation, and resources to demystify the process.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include talking to a mental health professional.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends referral to a psychologist or psychiatrist specializing in oncology and discusses CBT as an evidence-based therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include talking to a social worker.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions social workers and patient navigators at cancer centers as supports.

criterion_scores.description: The response should discuss medical interventions to help with anxiety.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses short-term anti-anxiety medication (e.g., lorazepam) before the scan.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that severe anxiety related to upcoming scans is highly prevalent or very common among patients with pancreatic cancer or cancer in general.
criterion_scores.justification: It states scan anxiety is incredibly common among cancer patients.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly mentions at least two of the following resource types for managing treatment-related anxiety: psychotherapy, psychoeducation, supportive therapy, or integrative modalities.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions psychotherapy (CBT), supportive therapy (support groups), and integrative modalities (acupuncture, massage), meeting the requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly identifies Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) as the first-line or primary intervention for treatment-related anxiety in pancreatic cancer or cancer patients, and attributes this recommendation to a major oncology guideline.
criterion_scores.justification: While CBT is mentioned as evidence-based, it is not identified as first-line/primary nor attributed to a major oncology guideline.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly mentions mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) or mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) as recommended for anxiety in cancer patients, and attributes this recommendation to a major oncology guideline.
criterion_scores.justification: Mindfulness apps are suggested, but MBIs/MBSR and guideline-based recommendations are not explicitly cited.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that pharmacologic therapy may be considered for severe anxiety or when first-line psychological interventions are insufficient, and that this is a secondary option with weaker evidence, as per a major oncology guideline.
criterion_scores.justification: Pharmacologic therapy is mentioned, but the response does not frame it as secondary with weaker evidence nor cite a major oncology guideline.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include open communication with the family.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicit section on fostering open, age-appropriate communication, including family check-ins, tailoring discussions to children's ages, and counseling support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include maintaining daily routines.
criterion_scores.justification: Direct recommendation to stick to routines with concrete examples (mealtimes, bedtimes, school/work routines) and use of shared calendars.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include continuing to do activities that bring enjoyment.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages continuing or adapting favorite activities (e.g., at-home picnics, virtual game nights) and creating new traditions to sustain joy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include letting the support system help.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends leveraging friends/family/community via meal trains, support groups (PanCAN, Cancer Support Community), and school/workplace resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include ensuring self-care for the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses patient self-care (rest, light hobbies) and proactive symptom management with the care team to minimize disruptions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include ensuring self-care for the support system.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides caregiver self-care strategies (short walks, journaling, hobbies), monitoring for burnout, and accessing therapy or mindfulness apps.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that pancreatic cancer imposes profound emotional, social, and practical upheaval on both the patient and family, disrupting established routines, roles, and relationships.
criterion_scores.justification: While it acknowledges challenges and disruptions to routines, it does not explicitly state the profound emotional, social, and practical upheaval or role/relationship disruptions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that early integration of supportive and palliative care is recommended.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of palliative care or early supportive care integration.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that referrals to registered dietitians and symptom management specialists can help minimize disruptions to family life.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention referrals to a registered dietitian or symptom management specialists; references only the general 'care team.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that caregiver and family support resources can provide education, emotional support, and practical assistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Highlights support groups (emotional support), meal trains and community help (practical assistance), and PanCAN patient navigators guiding communication (educational support).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the literature notes persistent gaps in support for caregivers and families affected by pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No reference to literature or persistent gaps in caregiver/family support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the user discuss this case with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not recommend discussing the case specifically with the oncologist; mentions the care team and external resources but no explicit oncologist referral.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing genetic counseling with the oncology team or healthcare provider in the context of pancreatic cancer care.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly advises discussing with the oncologist and requesting a referral (e.g., 'Ask your loved one's oncologist for a referral...' and 'it's worth discussing with your oncologist').

criterion_scores.description: The response should accurately describe the role of a genetic counselor as a trained professional who helps individuals and families understand the genetic aspects of disease, provides information, guidance, and support for informed decision-making, and assists with risk assessment and testing.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes genetic counselors as trained professionals, outlines goals (understanding genetics, risk assessment, informed decisions), and emphasizes supportive counseling beyond testing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that genetic counseling involves a structured evaluation of personal and family cancer history.
criterion_scores.justification: It details an initial consultation with a pedigree and review of family history including cancers and ages at diagnosis, indicating a structured history evaluation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that genetic counseling involves education about hereditary cancer syndromes.
criterion_scores.justification: It educates about hereditary syndromes relevant to pancreatic cancer (e.g., BRCA1/2, PALB2, ATM, CDKN2A, Lynch, Peutz-Jeghers, FAMMM).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that genetic counseling involves a discussion of the risks, benefits, and limitations of genetic testing.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses pros/cons, test types (panel vs targeted), limitations (VUS, not all risks detectable), accuracy, costs/coverage, and potential impacts.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that genetic counseling addresses the psychological and ethical aspects of genetic information, including communication of results to family members and consideration of reproductive implications.
criterion_scores.justification: It covers psychological impact, privacy/insurance ethics (GINA), and communicating results to family, but does not address reproductive implications or family planning; therefore it does not fully meet the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the American Society of Clinical Oncology recommends that this process be conducted with providers experienced in hereditary cancer syndromes.
criterion_scores.justification: Although ASCO is mentioned generally, there is no explicit statement that ASCO recommends counseling be conducted with providers experienced in hereditary cancer syndromes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the American Society of Clinical Oncology recommends that germline genetic testing be offered early in the disease course, ideally using a multigene panel that includes genes linked to pancreatic cancer risk such as BRCA1, BRCA2, and others.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses panel testing and relevant genes but does not state ASCO’s recommendation to offer germline testing early in the disease course or attribute these points to ASCO.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that neuropathy is a common side effect from certain chemotherapy drugs.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states PN is common and often caused by chemotherapy drugs, naming oxaliplatin, paclitaxel, and vincristine.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing medication side effects with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises discussing with the oncologist (and neurologist/palliative care) to tailor recommendations and monitor for interactions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that neuropathy from chemotherapy can be managed by dose reduction.
criterion_scores.justification: States that if neuropathy is chemo-related, the doctor might adjust the chemotherapy dose.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that neuropathy from chemotherapy can be managed by schedule modification.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions that the doctor might pause treatment temporarily, which constitutes schedule modification.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that neuropathy from chemotherapy can be managed by switching to an alternate regimen.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically says the doctor might switch drugs to prevent worsening neuropathy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that neuropathy from chemotherapy can be managed using supportive medications, including gabapentin.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists gabapentin as a commonly used medication for neuropathic pain.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including SNRIs.
criterion_scores.justification: Oxaliplatin is named as a causative agent, and duloxetine (an SNRI) is recommended for chemotherapy-induced neuropathy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including pregabalin.
criterion_scores.justification: Oxaliplatin is listed among causative drugs, and pregabalin is recommended for neuropathic pain/CIPN.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include physical therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends physical therapy for balance, strength, mobility and fall-risk reduction.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include occupational therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends occupational therapy and adaptive tools to aid daily activities.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that peripheral neuropathy could arise from chemotherapy (notably platinum agents), direct tumor involvement, or paraneoplastic syndromes.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions chemotherapy (including oxaliplatin) and 'the cancer itself,' but does not mention paraneoplastic syndromes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that peripheral neuropathy significantly impairs quality of life and functional status.
criterion_scores.justification: States treatment aims include improving quality of life; discusses mobility/fall risk and daily function via PT/OT, implying functional impairment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that management should be individualized, balancing efficacy, side effects, and patient-specific factors.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes best approach depends on severity, cause, overall health, and emphasizes tailored recommendations and monitoring for interactions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that Duloxetine is the only agent with moderate evidence-based recommendation for the treatment of chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) in cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions duloxetine as helpful but does not state it is the only agent with moderate evidence-based recommendation for CIPN.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the typical starting dose of duloxetine is 30 mg daily, titrated to 60 mg daily as tolerated, with slow tapering recommended to avoid withdrawal symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides no dosing or tapering details for duloxetine.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that other pharmacologic options include tricyclic antidepressants (nortriptyline, amitriptyline), gabapentin, and pregabalin, which are supported by guidelines for cancer-related neuropathic pain but have inconclusive evidence.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions gabapentin and pregabalin but does not mention tricyclic antidepressants or the guideline context/inconclusive evidence.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that topical agents such as lidocaine and capsaicin patches may be considered for localized neuropathic pain, though evidence is limited.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists lidocaine and capsaicin for localized pain but does not qualify that supporting evidence is limited.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that opioids are not preferred for chronic neuropathic pain due to risk of tolerance, dependence, and adverse effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Suggests opioids for severe pain with caution but does not state they are not preferred for chronic neuropathic pain.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that interventional approaches, notably neurolytic celiac plexus block, are effective for refractory pain in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions nerve blocks generally but does not reference neurolytic celiac plexus block for pancreatic cancer pain.

criterion_scores.description: Define curative treatment as interventions with the intent to eradicate the disease and achieve long-term survival.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states curative treatment aims to completely eliminate the cancer so it doesn't return and achieve a cure, aligning with eradication and long-term survival.

criterion_scores.description: Include that curative treatment can include surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: Surgery (e.g., Whipple procedure) is clearly listed as a curative option.

criterion_scores.description: Mention that in curative treatment, surgery is often followed by adjuvant chemotherapy to reduce recurrence risk.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes chemotherapy and/or radiation may be used after surgery to kill remaining cancer cells, which conveys the concept of adjuvant therapy aimed at reducing recurrence.

criterion_scores.description: Define palliative treatment as focusing on improving quality of life when cure is not possible.
criterion_scores.justification: It defines palliative care as relieving symptoms, managing pain, and improving quality of life rather than trying to cure the cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Mention that palliative treatment is the case for the majority of patients with locally advanced unresectable or metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states surgery is feasible in only 15–20% of cases and that palliative care is common in advanced pancreatic cancer; it also notes many cases are diagnosed at stage 3 or 4 when the cancer has spread, implying most patients require palliative approaches.

criterion_scores.description: Include that the primary goal of palliative treatment is to prolong survival, control symptoms, and maintain quality of life.
criterion_scores.justification: While symptom control and quality of life are emphasized, the response does not explicitly state that prolonging survival is a primary goal of palliative treatment.

criterion_scores.description: Include that palliative treatment can include chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Palliative chemotherapy is explicitly mentioned as an option to slow tumor growth and ease symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: Include that palliative treatment can include radiation for local control or pain.
criterion_scores.justification: Palliative radiation is mentioned as a means to slow tumor growth and ease symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: Include that palliative treatment can include pain management.
criterion_scores.justification: Pain management, including medications and nerve blocks, is specifically discussed.

criterion_scores.description: Mention that palliative approaches include endoscopic or surgical procedures to relieve biliary or gastric outlet obstruction, and comprehensive supportive care for pain, nutrition, and psychosocial needs.
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes biliary stents for jaundice (endoscopic relief of obstruction) and comprehensive supportive care such as pain management, nutritional support, and counseling (psychosocial).

criterion_scores.description: Mention that the American Society of Clinical Oncology emphasizes early integration of palliative care for all patients with advanced disease.
criterion_scores.justification: ASCO is not mentioned, and there is no explicit citation of guideline-backed early integration, despite noting that palliative care can be provided at any stage.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend that the user discuss this case with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises discussing with the mother's oncologist or a palliative care specialist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the costs.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicit 'Financial Aspects' section details cost ranges, itemized expenses, insurance issues, and funding options.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing treatment decisions with your oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Multiple clear recommendations to consult the oncologist, seek a second opinion at major cancer centers, and coordinate with the home medical team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the stage of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly advise confirming or considering the cancer stage in decision-making.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the type of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention pancreatic cancer subtype (e.g., adenocarcinoma vs. neuroendocrine) or explicitly advise clarifying tumor type.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the reputation of the clinic.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises assessing facility reputation, international accreditation (JCI/ISQua), and cautions against unregulated clinics.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the qualifications of the providers.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends verifying doctors’ credentials, board certifications, publication history, and pancreatic cancer experience.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the details of the experimental treatments, including types of drugs.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages identifying the exact therapy type and provides examples (immunotherapy, gene therapy, CAR-T, PARP inhibitors), with guidance to differentiate experimental vs. unproven.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the evidence supporting the treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Directs readers to peer-reviewed studies, ClinicalTrials.gov, Cochrane, and trial phases with attention to efficacy and survival data.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the potential side effects of the experimental treatments.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically advises researching risks and side effects, and notes potential worsening of symptoms and interactions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the safety of the drugs.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions Phase 1 safety focus, regulatory status, ethical standards, and FDA warnings—explicitly addressing safety assessment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the legal protections of the country.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers country-specific regulation, approval status, ethics (Declaration of Helsinki), liability considerations, and legal issues.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the availability of medical records.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises compiling a 'treatment dossier' with medical records and ensuring a plan for sharing results with the home team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the logistics of traveling abroad for treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a 'Logistics and Support' section covering flights, transport, accommodations, translators, and emergency services.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention considering your loved one’s health and travel suitability, as long travel can be taxing.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes travel can be physically taxing, discusses medical transport, and the demands on someone with cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention considering if the other country has specialized high-quality pancreatic cancer care.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises choosing accredited facilities, assessing provider pancreatic cancer experience, and researching country-level regulation, implying evaluation of specialized high-quality care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention considering visa barriers when traveling abroad for treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions researching medical visas.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention considering local accommodations when traveling abroad for treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Travel planning includes accommodations near the facility.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention considering cultural barriers when traveling abroad for treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses language/cultural barriers by recommending translators and local support resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention considering challenges with follow-up care when traveling abroad for treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes creating a follow-up plan, result sharing with home team, and notes potential illegality of continuing unapproved treatments at home.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention considering social support challenges when traveling abroad for treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Highlights caregiver presence, local support groups, and the stress/isolation of being abroad.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe why treatments for pancreatic cancer can increase the risk of infections, including immunosuppression due to chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly explains that chemotherapy, radiation, and surgery can weaken the immune system, cause neutropenia (low white blood cells), and increase infection risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend hand hygiene.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a dedicated section on hand hygiene with specifics on washing and use of alcohol-based sanitizer for all household members and visitors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend avoiding sick contacts.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises avoiding crowds and people who are sick and screening visitors to ensure they are healthy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend being up to date on age-appropriate vaccinations.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends staying up to date with influenza, pneumococcal, and COVID-19 vaccines with oncologist approval, and vaccinating household members.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing the infections with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Repeatedly encourages consulting the oncology team, scheduling a meeting for an infection-prevention plan, and contacting the doctor immediately for fever.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend food safety.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes detailed food safety guidance (avoiding undercooked/raw foods, unpasteurized products, and careful handling/cooking) and mentions neutropenic diet if advised.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend adherence with prophylactic medications if prescribed.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states to take prescribed prophylactic antibiotics, antifungals, or growth factors as directed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention avoiding exposure to fungal spores, especially for patients with neutropenia, by avoiding environments with high concentrations of airborne fungal spores.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises avoiding construction areas or moldy environments due to fungal risks and discusses air quality measures.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that there is no need for antimicrobial prophylaxis for most solid tumors if the overall infection risk is low (neutropenia < 7 days).
criterion_scores.justification: Does not state that antimicrobial prophylaxis is generally not needed for most solid tumors with short-duration neutropenia; instead emphasizes taking prophylaxis if prescribed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that interventions such as footwear exchange, protected environments, neutropenic diet, or nutritional supplements are not recommended due to a lack of evidence of clinical benefit.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention the lack of evidence for these interventions; in fact, suggests a neutropenic diet and creating a 'protective bubble,' which runs counter to the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes the combination of immune checkpoint blockade with chemotherapy as a current research strategy in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicit section on 'Checkpoint Inhibitors Combined with Chemotherapy' with examples (pembrolizumab or nivolumab plus gemcitabine/nab-paclitaxel or FOLFIRINOX) and trials (PRINCE, UPenn Phase 2, KEYNOTE-937).

criterion_scores.description: The response describes the combination of immune checkpoint blockade with radiation as a current research strategy in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'Radiation + Immunotherapy' with SBRT combined with durvalumab (PD-L1 inhibitor) to produce an in situ vaccine effect.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes the combination of immune checkpoint blockade with other novel agents (e.g., targeted therapies, immune modulators, or agents targeting the tumor microenvironment) as a current research strategy in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions combinations with CD40 agonist (sotigalimab), PARP inhibitors, stromal-targeting agent PEGPH20, anti-CD47, vaccines, and oncolytic viruses alongside PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitors.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly defines immunotherapy as a treatment that uses the body’s immune system to attack cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses harnessing the immune system and 'cold' TME but does not provide an explicit definition that immunotherapy uses the body's immune system to attack cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that pembrolizumab is approved for pancreatic cancer with MSI-high tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states 'For MSI-high pancreatic cancers (rare, about 1-2%), pembrolizumab is already approved.'

criterion_scores.description: The response states that pembrolizumab is approved for pancreatic cancer with dMMR (deficient mismatch repair) tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of dMMR approval; only MSI-H approval is stated.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that pembrolizumab is approved for pancreatic cancer with TMB-high (tumor mutational burden-high) tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: TMB is referenced as a biomarker under study but no statement that pembrolizumab is approved for TMB-high tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response specifically mentions clinicaltrials.gov as a resource for finding immunotherapy clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly advises searching ClinicalTrials.gov for pancreatic cancer immunotherapy combinations.

criterion_scores.description: The response specifically mentions the PanCan clinical trial finder as a resource for finding immunotherapy clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions PanCAN and 'Patient Central' but does not specifically name the PanCAN Clinical Trial Finder.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes immune checkpoint blockade as a current strategy for studying immunotherapy in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Multiple sections detail PD-1/PD-L1 and CTLA-4 inhibitors and their combinations as active research strategies.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes adoptive cellular therapy (e.g., CAR-T cell therapy or modified T-cells) as a current research strategy in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicit section on CAR-T cells targeting mesothelin in early-phase trials, including combination with checkpoint inhibitors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that current research on immunotherapy combinations for patients with pancreatic cancer is focused on overcoming the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment (TME) and enhancing antitumor immune responses.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes 'cold' TME, tumor immune suppression, and goals to make tumors more visible and enhance immune infiltration.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that neoadjuvant immunotherapy combinations are being tested to prime the immune system before surgery, with early results suggesting potential improvements in disease-free and overall survival.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions a trial in resectable disease (KEYNOTE-937) but does not specify neoadjuvant priming before surgery or report early improvements in DFS/OS.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that cancer vaccines are under investigation as an immunotherapy approach for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a dedicated 'Immunotherapy with Vaccines' section with examples (GVAX, personalized neoantigen vaccines, CRS-207).

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the user discuss this case with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly advises discussing treatment options with an oncologist or pancreatic cancer specialist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the goal of the study.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly asks, “What is the main purpose of this study?” which directly addresses understanding the study’s goal.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the phase of the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes, “What phase is the study in?” and explains what each phase generally evaluates (safety, effectiveness, comparison, long-term effects).

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the eligibility requirements of the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Asks about inclusion/exclusion criteria and whether the patient qualifies, with examples (stage, health, prior treatments).

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the potential side effects of the treatments.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicit question: “What are the known risks or side effects?” with examples of common toxicities.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding if there are additional tests required to participate in the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes, “How will you determine if he's a good fit? (What tests or screenings are needed before enrollment?).”

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding if there are travel costs associated with the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses costs and reimbursement explicitly, including travel coverage and compensation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the evidence supporting the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Prompts to ask, “What have been the results so far in this study or similar ones?” and to seek data on response, survival, QoL.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the kind of treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Asks, “What treatments or interventions are involved?” with examples (chemotherapy, immunotherapy, targeted therapy, surgery).

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the visit schedule of the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers frequency of visits, schedule, follow-up duration, and travel cadence.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that research studies are designed to determine if a new medical strategy, treatment, or device is safe and/or effective for humans.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains trial phases: Phase 1 (Safety) and Phase 2 (Effectiveness), which explicitly conveys that trials assess safety and effectiveness.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that clinical trials are essential for improving, optimizing, or advancing current and/or future cancer therapies.
criterion_scores.justification: While it notes access to new treatments, it does not explicitly state that trials are essential for advancing cancer therapies.

criterion_scores.description: The response includes the question: “How will participation impact current treatment and care?”
criterion_scores.justification: Directly asks, “Can he continue his current treatments or medications while in the study?” which captures the impact on current care.

criterion_scores.description: The response includes the question: “What are the implications for family members, especially if genetic testing is involved?”
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of genetic testing or family implications is included.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing the case with an oncologist or relevant healthcare professional to review trial details and discuss pros and cons.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises discussing with the father’s oncologist or the study’s principal investigator and mentions second opinions and patient advocates.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe non-opioid medications for pain control, including acetaminophen.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions acetaminophen (Tylenol) as a non-opioid option with brief guidance on monitoring.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe non-opioid medications for pain control, including NSAIDs.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen) and COX-2 inhibitors (celecoxib) with cautions on GI/kidney risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe non-opioid medications for neuropathic pain, including gabapentin.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes gabapentin under anticonvulsants for neuropathic pain management.
