criterion_scores.justification: Explains the rationale clearly: address multiple pathways, prevent/overcome resistance, and potentially improve outcomes versus single-agent therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain why the patient’s tumor tissue needs to undergo molecular testing to understand what targeted therapies are indicated.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes genomic testing (NGS, liquid biopsy) to identify actionable mutations that determine suitability and selection of targeted therapies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain that some targeted therapies may not work on the patient’s tumor due to lack of targetable mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: States that not everyone qualifies; if no targets are found, targeted therapy may not be appropriate and chemotherapy may be prioritized.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain that targeted therapies do not always work in pancreatic cancer due to tumor heterogeneity.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes pancreatic cancer often involves multiple genetic changes and that single targets may be insufficient; mentions resistance and modest response rates, reflecting heterogeneity as a reason for limited efficacy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that targeted therapies are sometimes used at the same time as traditional chemotherapies.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly cites targeted therapy plus chemotherapy (e.g., erlotinib with gemcitabine) as a combination approach.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss this further with their oncologist as targeted therapies are individualized to each patient’s cancer, and not all targeted therapies are treatment options for all patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages discussion with the oncology team, emphasizes individualized decisions, and provides specific questions to ask, noting not all patients are candidates.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention KRAS inhibitors as a current area of research in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions emerging KRAS inhibitors (sotorasib, adagrasib) and notes their use in clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention PARP inhibitors are used in pancreatic cancer patients with BRCA1/2 mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically cites olaparib (a PARP inhibitor) for tumors with BRCA mutations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define metastasis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly defines metastasis as cancer cells breaking away from the primary tumor and traveling to other parts of the body, specifying that this occurs via the bloodstream or lymphatic system.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain how cancer metastasizes, such as hematologic spread and lymphatic spread.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions spread through the bloodstream and lymphatic system, covering both hematogenous and lymphatic routes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how pancreatic cancer metastasizes.
criterion_scores.justification: The response describes pancreatic cancer's tendency to spread early, notes portal venous drainage to the liver, and outlines typical metastatic patterns and sites.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that pancreatic cancer typically spreads locally first, involving surrounding lymph nodes, organs, and blood vessels.
criterion_scores.justification: While it says head-of-pancreas cancers often spread locally before distant metastasis and that regional lymph nodes are involved early, it does not explicitly state that pancreatic cancer typically spreads locally first overall nor mention local spread to blood vessels.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that metastatic spread of the pancreatic cancer can be influenced by the location of the primary tumor, for example whether it is located at the pancreatic head or the tail.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly notes that tumor location (head vs tail) influences spread patterns, with head tumors often spreading locally first and tail tumors potentially metastasizing earlier to distant sites.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that the liver is usually the first location for metastases.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states the liver is the primary/most common site of distant metastasis but does not explicitly state it is usually the first location for metastases.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that pancreatic cancer can metastasize to the peritoneum or lining of the abdominal cavity.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly lists the peritoneum as a site of metastasis and describes associated ascites.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that pancreatic cancer can spread to the lungs.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions the lungs as a metastatic site.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that pancreatic cancer can spread to at least one of the following less common sites: bones, brain, or adrenal gland.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists bones, brain/CNS, and adrenal glands among less common sites.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain what proportion of pancreatic cancers are metastatic at diagnosis and why.
criterion_scores.justification: It states about 50–80% have spread at diagnosis and attributes this to lack of early symptoms due to the pancreas’s deep location.

criterion_scores.description: The response should discuss that pancreatic cancer commonly has already metastasized at the time of diagnosis because it often is asymptomatic at an early stage and only becomes symptomatic, prompting diagnostic investigation, once it has spread beyond its original site.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly explains that pancreatic cancer is often asymptomatic early, leading to late diagnosis and frequent metastasis by the time it is detected.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that treatment options exist for all stages of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: While it discusses treatment options for metastatic disease, it does not explicitly state that treatment options exist for all stages.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that options for treatment modalities, for example surgery or chemotherapy, depend on the stage of the cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It links treatment decisions to staging by stating that specifics are based on imaging and staging, and it lists modalities that vary by stage (e.g., surgery vs palliative approaches).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how pancreatic cancer chemotherapy treatment can cause injury to the kidneys.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly explains that chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine, FOLFIRINOX, platinum agents) can cause direct nephrotoxicity, dehydration, and AKI, with monitoring via BUN/creatinine and GFR.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that platinum drugs (e.g., cisplatin, oxaliplatin) can directly injure the kidney.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions platinum-based agents such as cisplatin and links them to kidney effects and direct toxicity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how other pancreatic cancer treatments, such as surgery or radiation, can cause injury to the kidneys.
criterion_scores.justification: No discussion of kidney injury related to surgery or radiation was provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that urinary tract infection should be ruled out, as some cancer treatments can put patients at increased risk for infection.
criterion_scores.justification: While infection prevention is mentioned in general terms, there is no explicit mention of ruling out urinary tract infections.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that patients undergoing systemic treatment for pancreatic cancer should have their kidney function monitored frequently to evaluate for toxicity.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends frequent blood and urine tests and early detection through regular labs to monitor kidney function.

criterion_scores.description: The response must clearly state that the first step is to identify the offending agent and reduce or hold the drug.
criterion_scores.justification: Although dose reduction, switching, or pausing therapy is discussed, it does not state that the first step is to identify the offending agent and hold or reduce it.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways that renal toxicity related to pancreatic cancer treatment is monitored and managed, such as serial lab tests of renal function to understand if it is improving over time.
criterion_scores.justification: It details serial monitoring with frequent blood and urine tests and tracking electrolytes and proteinuria.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways that renal toxicity related to pancreatic cancer treatment is managed, such as dose reduction of systemic treatment, particularly the offending drugs.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends dose reduction, switching to less nephrotoxic agents (e.g., cisplatin to carboplatin), and temporary treatment pauses.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways that renal toxicity related to pancreatic cancer treatment is managed, such as administration of intravenous fluids or other medications to support the kidneys.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends IV fluids and mentions supportive medications (e.g., antiemetics, amifostine, mannitol) and diuretics/BP meds for symptom management.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that IV fluids can be used to provide hydration.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states that intravenous (IV) hydration is used before, during, and after chemotherapy to maintain kidney perfusion and flush toxins.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways that renal toxicity related to pancreatic cancer treatment is managed, such as thorough evaluation of other medications or supplements a patient is taking to ensure there are no harmful interactions.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises reviewing medications to avoid nephrotoxic agents (NSAIDs, some antibiotics) and contrast dyes, indicating medication reconciliation.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that alleviating obstruction (e.g., via stenting or nephrostomy) can help recover renal function.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of urinary tract obstruction management such as ureteral stents or nephrostomy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that dehydration and obstruction (e.g., biliary or urinary) can lead to kidney injury.
criterion_scores.justification: Dehydration is discussed, but obstruction (urinary or biliary) as a cause of kidney injury is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient consult with their oncology team and oncology pharmacist prior to starting new medications or supplements while undergoing pancreatic cancer treatment to avoid harmful interactions.
criterion_scores.justification: It does not advise consulting the oncology team or oncology pharmacist before starting new medications or supplements.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that sometimes dialysis may be indicated if there is a severe kidney injury related to cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that temporary dialysis might be needed in severe cases of kidney failure.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend staying well hydrated and with adequate nutrition intake while undergoing pancreatic cancer treatment to preserve energy and organ functions.
criterion_scores.justification: It encourages oral fluid intake and provides dietary guidance (renal diet, lean proteins, avoidance of processed foods), supporting hydration and nutrition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of genetic mutations in cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explains that cancer begins with DNA mutations and gives pancreatic-specific examples (KRAS as a 'gas pedal', TP53 as 'brakes', mentions SMAD4), linking these mutations to uncontrolled growth and progression from PanIN to invasive cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain how cancer treatment applies selective pressure on cancer cells, allowing those that harbor certain characteristics that confer resistance to therapy a survival advantage.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states that treatments kill sensitive cells while resistant subclones survive and expand, framing this as an evolutionary process under selective pressure with examples relevant to pancreatic cancer (gemcitabine, FOLFIRINOX).

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain that after certain treatments, tumor cells susceptible to that treatment will have died while those resistant to the treatment survive, making the residual cancer fundamentally different from the original cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states that when treatment kills sensitive cells, resistant ones survive, multiply, and become dominant, leading to recurrence/progression—indicating the post-treatment tumor composition differs from the original.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how genetic mutations can cause cancer cells to resist certain treatments.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes that a subset of cells may harbor mutations that make them resistant to therapy and survive treatment, conveying that genetic alterations underlie resistance, even if mechanistic details are not deeply elaborated.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the heterogeneous cellular make-up of pancreatic cancer at baseline.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly describes intratumoral heterogeneity, multiple clones with different mutations, and emphasizes that pancreatic cancer is often heterogeneous from the start.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the mesenchymal-epithelial transition, including triggers for this phenomenon.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of mesenchymal-epithelial transition (MET) or its triggers (nor epithelial-mesenchymal transition); invasion and stromal interactions are discussed but MET is not described.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe methods for evaluating tumor evolution over time, including circulating tumor DNA and/or traditional biopsy of the primary tumor or metastatic lesion.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions liquid biopsies to track tumor DNA changes over time and suggests genomic testing of the tumor; also references serial imaging and biomarkers, satisfying inclusion of ctDNA-based monitoring.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that tumor evolution is when the cancer changes and adapts over time.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly defines tumor evolution as how cancer cells change and adapt over time.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define complementary therapies, including supportive and integrative therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines complementary therapies as non-mainstream approaches used alongside standard treatment and explicitly notes they are also called integrative or supportive therapies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define aromatherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a clear definition: use of essential oils from plants, often inhaled or applied topically, for relaxation and symptom relief.

criterion_scores.description: Mention that ingested/applied substances can cause reactions (e.g., allergic), that it may be difficult to tell if a reaction is from the complementary therapy or the cancer treatment, and thus should be used with caution.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses allergic/irritant risks and advises caution, but does not explicitly state the difficulty of distinguishing whether reactions are due to the complementary therapy versus the cancer treatment.

criterion_scores.description: Inform patients that complementary therapies do not treat cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States that aromatherapy does not treat or cure cancer and emphasizes complementary therapies are supportive and not replacements for conventional care.

criterion_scores.description: Inform patients that some complementary therapies may help with symptoms related to their cancer diagnosis, such as stress or insomnia.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes potential benefits for symptom management, including nausea, anxiety, stress, and sleep issues.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend the patient inquire with their oncology team if there are practitioners of complementary therapies that they trust, or can place a referral to.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises discussing with the oncology team and mentions that some cancer centers have integrative programs, implying referral/connection to trusted practitioners.

criterion_scores.description: Provide website links to informational pages from cancer societies such as NCI or PanCAN.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides specific reputable resources: NCI (cancer.gov), American Cancer Society (cancer.org), PanCAN (pancan.org), and Macmillan; adequate as links/resources to informational pages.

criterion_scores.description: Strongly recommend that the patient discuss any complementary therapies they are considering with their oncology team to ensure there are no harmful interactions with their cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Repeatedly emphasizes consulting the oncology team before starting any therapy and references potential interactions with treatments.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that aromatherapy is safest when used through inhalation and that oils must be appropriately prepared.
criterion_scores.justification: States that inhalation is usually safer and recommends starting with diffusion; also advises using a diluted topical blend, indicating appropriate preparation.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that essential oils on the skin should be used with caution due to the risk of worsening skin irritation from chemotherapy or radiation.
criterion_scores.justification: Warns that topical application can irritate sensitive skin, especially with radiation therapy or chemo-related rashes, aligning with a cautionary message.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define metabolism in humans.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines metabolism as how cells convert nutrients (glucose, fats, proteins) into energy and building blocks, and notes regulation in healthy cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the Warburg Effect.
criterion_scores.justification: Accurately describes the Warburg effect: preference for glycolysis despite oxygen presence, production of lactate, and links to rapid growth and survival.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include information about glucose, amino acid, and lipid metabolism in cancer cells, specifically in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses glucose dependency, glutamine (amino acid) addiction, and lipid metabolism specifically in pancreatic cancer, including KRAS context.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that changes in metabolism can alter sensitivity to cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states metabolic adaptations contribute to chemo resistance and that targeting metabolism may enhance sensitivity to treatments.

criterion_scores.description: The response should not recommend specific diets for the management of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses ketogenic diets and fasting as areas of study but does not recommend them; emphasizes limited evidence and need for medical supervision.

criterion_scores.description: The response should not indicate that restrictive diets, such as the ketogenic diet or intermittent fasting, should be started by patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not advise starting restrictive diets; explicitly cautions about doing so only under medical supervision.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss diet with their oncologist and request a referral to a nutritionist if they are interested in learning more.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages discussion with the oncology team but does not specifically recommend discussing diet nor suggest a referral to a nutritionist/dietitian.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there is not any current evidence for dietary interventions to alter the metabolism of the cancer and improve treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: States evidence is limited and not conclusive and cites small studies suggesting potential benefit, which does not meet the requirement to state there is no current evidence.

criterion_scores.description: Lists causes of eye problems related to cancer/treatment, including chemo-induced optic neuropathy, immunotherapy-related inflammation, bleeding, cataracts, dry eye, metastatic disease to the brain or eye, and infections.
criterion_scores.justification: The response mentions several causes (chemo-related dry eye/irritation and optic nerve/retinal damage; immunotherapy-related inflammation; radiation-related cataracts; infections; and metastasis affecting vision), but it does not mention bleeding. Because not all specified causes (notably bleeding) are included, full credit cannot be awarded.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly states that chemotherapy can lead to eye dryness and irritations.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states under chemotherapy: "These might include: Dry eyes, irritation, or excessive tearing."

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly states that the use of steroids can lead to an increase in cataracts or glaucoma.
criterion_scores.justification: Although steroids are mentioned as possible treatments, the response does not state that steroid use can increase the risk of cataracts or glaucoma.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly states that immunosuppressed patients are more likely to have infections in their eyes.
criterion_scores.justification: The response mentions infections as possible causes but does not explicitly state that immunosuppressed patients are at higher risk for eye infections.

criterion_scores.description: Mentions that symptoms may not be related to cancer/treatment and recommends an eye exam by a qualified practitioner.
criterion_scores.justification: States symptoms might not be treatment-related (could be age-related changes, infections, allergies, other conditions) and recommends seeing an ophthalmologist for a thorough exam.

criterion_scores.description: Recommends documenting characteristics of symptoms (e.g., severity, date of onset).
criterion_scores.justification: Advises keeping a symptom journal noting when issues started, what makes them better/worse, and patterns with treatment cycles.

criterion_scores.description: Lists red-flag eye symptoms prompting immediate medical care (e.g., vision loss, severe pain).
criterion_scores.justification: Lists urgent symptoms: sudden/severe vision loss; persistent pain, redness, or swelling; double vision, floaters, flashes; rapidly worsening symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly states that any eye symptoms should be discussed with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises to contact the oncologist immediately and report symptoms; also mentions reaching out to the medical team even after hours.

criterion_scores.description: Recommends possibly requesting a referral to an ophthalmologist based on symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically recommends seeing an ophthalmologist and notes the oncologist may refer to a specialist.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly states that eye drops can mitigate symptoms of dry eyes.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions artificial tears and preservative-free lubricating drops to help with dryness.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define neoantigens in cancer as proteins expressed on the surface of cancer cells, used by the immune system to differentiate cancer from healthy tissue.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly defines neoantigens as new proteins/fragments that appear on the surface of cancer cells but not healthy cells and explains that the immune system can recognize them as foreign. This satisfies the requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention ongoing research involving neoantigens in cancer, including cancer vaccines, immunotherapy, and CAR-T trials.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses ongoing research including personalized neoantigen vaccines (with trial examples), checkpoint inhibitor immunotherapy, and adoptive cell therapy involving engineered T cells. While it does not explicitly say 'CAR-T,' adoptive cell therapy encompasses CAR-T approaches, meeting the intent of the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there are no FDA-approved treatments targeting neoantigens at this time.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes that neoantigen vaccines are mostly in clinical trials but does not explicitly state that there are no FDA-approved treatments targeting neoantigens, as required.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss the role of neoantigens in their cancer care with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly encourages discussion with the oncology team and provides specific questions to ask about neoantigens and treatment planning.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend considering referral to be considered for clinical trials for pancreatic cancer treatment in their area.
criterion_scores.justification: The response recommends clinical trials, suggests searching ClinicalTrials.gov, and advises asking doctors about eligibility, effectively guiding toward referral/consideration for trials.

criterion_scores.description: Define autophagy, including normal role in cellular turnover, degradation and recycling of cellular components, and maintaining homeostasis by removing damaged organelles and protein aggregates.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly defines autophagy as a process of breaking down and recycling cellular components and describes it as cellular housekeeping. It explicitly mentions removal of damaged proteins and organelles, recycling, and maintaining cellular health/quality control, which together capture cellular homeostasis and turnover. While 'protein aggregates' is not stated verbatim, the concepts of 'faulty proteins' and preventing buildup of harmful materials adequately cover this.

criterion_scores.description: Describe the dual role of autophagy in cancer (tumor suppression and promotion) and how roles change during progression.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly describes autophagy as a double-edged sword: tumor-suppressive in early stages by removing damaged components and tumor-promoting in established cancers by helping cells survive stress and resist treatment. It discusses context and progression clearly.

criterion_scores.description: State that autophagy can be protective against cancer by removing damaged or dysregulated proteins.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states autophagy prevents cancer initiation by clearing faulty proteins and damaged organelles, thereby preventing buildup of harmful materials that could lead to mutations.

criterion_scores.description: Describe autophagy in pancreatic adenocarcinoma, addressing upregulation and contribution to survival and treatment resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: It specifically notes elevated basal autophagy in PDAC, association with KRAS mutations, and links autophagy to survival in nutrient-poor/low-oxygen environments and resistance to chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine).

criterion_scores.description: State that cancer cells utilize autophagy to promote survival, growth, and therapy resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explains cancer cells hijack autophagy to generate energy and building blocks, resist apoptosis, metastasize, and resist chemotherapy, addressing survival, growth, and therapy resistance.

criterion_scores.description: Explain if autophagy can be targeted with cancer treatment, providing at least one reference with a PMID if available.
criterion_scores.justification: While it explains autophagy can be targeted and mentions chloroquine/hydroxychloroquine and trials, it provides no references or PMIDs.

criterion_scores.description: State that blocking autophagy has been explored but there are no current standard of care treatments targeting autophagy in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes that autophagy inhibitors are being tested in clinical trials and explicitly states these are experimental and not standard treatments, satisfying the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: Mention specific drugs targeting autophagy, reference existing evidence in the literature, and clearly state if any strategy is FDA approved.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions specific drugs (CQ/HCQ) and trials but does not cite literature and does not clearly state FDA approval status for autophagy-targeting strategies (no explicit mention of FDA).

criterion_scores.description: Reference at least one scientific literature source with a PubMed ID (PMID).
criterion_scores.justification: No PMIDs or specific literature citations are provided.

criterion_scores.description: Describe the different types of support groups that exist for cancer patients and family members of cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: The response distinguishes multiple types: telehealth vs in-person groups, patient vs caregiver-specific groups, one-on-one mentorship (Imerman Angels), moderated groups led by clinicians, online forums (ACS Cancer Survivors Network, Inspire), and mentions activity-based options (e.g., art therapy). It explicitly addresses both patients and family/caregivers.

criterion_scores.description: Address whether there is evidence that a telehealth support group is inferior to an in-person support group.
criterion_scores.justification: It states telehealth groups are often comparable to in-person groups, cites that in-person may have a slight edge in perceived social connectedness, and concludes telehealth is equally effective in key outcomes, directly addressing potential inferiority.

criterion_scores.description: Provide references and sources for evidence regarding the effectiveness of telehealth versus in-person support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: The response cites a 2021 review in Supportive Care in Cancer, a 2020 study in Psycho-Oncology, and mentions ACS and NCI as sources. While not fully formatted citations, these are identifiable references supporting claims.

criterion_scores.description: State that in-person and telehealth groups each have advantages and disadvantages and either may be as effective based on an individual’s needs and preferences.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly outlines pros and cons of both modalities, emphasizes individual preferences and needs, and states telehealth can be just as effective for many while in-person may better suit others.

criterion_scores.description: State that telehealth groups can be more accessible and convenient.
criterion_scores.justification: It highlights convenience (no commuting), flexibility of timing, broader reach (including rural areas), ability to join from home during immunosuppression, and privacy—explicitly addressing accessibility and convenience.

criterion_scores.description: State that some may feel that in-person groups will lead to better emotional connection.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes missing the 'human touch,' the value of physical presence, and that in-person has a slight edge in perceived social connectedness, satisfying the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: Include a way for the patient or family member to input their location to generate a list of local support group resources.
criterion_scores.justification: Although several organizations are listed, there is no specific tool or instruction for entering a location (e.g., ZIP code search link) to generate local resources.

criterion_scores.description: List organizations to contact that might be able to provide support resources.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists PanCAN (with phone and site), ACS (site), CancerCare (with phone and site), and Imerman Angels, which are appropriate organizations for support resources.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend that the patient ask their oncology team for assistance in finding support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly advises asking the oncologist or palliative care team for group recommendations, noting they may know local and virtual options.

criterion_scores.description: Describe that increased stress is normal when dealing with a cancer diagnosis and treatment, or as a family member of a cancer patient.
criterion_scores.justification: While empathetic language is used, the response does not explicitly normalize increased stress or state that such stress is common/expected in this context.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the effect of caffeine on sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises avoiding caffeine after noon as a stimulant that can disrupt sleep.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the effect of alcohol on sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: States to steer clear of alcohol because it can fragment sleep.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the effect of illegal drugs on sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of illegal/recreational drugs or their effects on sleep.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe strategies to improve sleep that are evidence-based.
criterion_scores.justification: Offers multiple evidence-based strategies: sleep hygiene, consistent schedule, stimulus control (get out of bed if not sleepy), optimizing environment, CBT-I, relaxation techniques, daytime light exercise, symptom management, and avoiding late-day vigorous exercise.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide references for evidence-based sleep improvement interventions.
criterion_scores.justification: Cites recognized organizations and resources (American Cancer Society, National Comprehensive Cancer Network patient guidelines, Sleep Foundation) and CBT-I programs (SHUTi, Sleepio), providing credible references.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include insights into things in everyday life that may be interfering with a patient’s ability to sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies practical daily-life factors: screen use/blue light, caffeine, alcohol, nicotine, irregular schedule, late vigorous exercise, and suboptimal bedroom conditions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide insights into how cancer-related symptoms can interfere with sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses pain, neuropathy, nausea, and anxiety related to cancer and its treatments as contributors to insomnia.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of appropriate management of cancer-related or cancer-treatment related symptoms to prevent interference in everyday life, including sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes working with the oncology team on pain control, anti-nausea regimens, and referrals (e.g., palliative care, sleep specialist) to manage symptoms affecting sleep.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe common symptoms that people with pancreatic cancer might experience.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions abdominal pain and digestive issues as symptoms; while not exhaustive (e.g., jaundice, weight loss), it does describe common experiences relevant to pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should direct the patient to discuss any symptoms of cancer or cancer treatment with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly advises discussing sleep issues and symptoms with the oncology team/sleep specialist and mentions potential referrals and adjustments by the medical team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of mental health and the impact of stress on sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses anxiety/stress as causes of insomnia and recommends mindfulness, relaxation techniques, and CBT-I.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that sleep hygiene is an important first step.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it provides a section on sleep hygiene, it does not explicitly state that sleep hygiene is an 'important first step.'

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention a consistent relaxing bedtime routine starting 30 to 60 minutes before bedtime.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically recommends winding down 30–60 minutes before bed with calming activities.

criterion_scores.description: The response must clearly state that stimulant use, such as nicotine, should be avoided in the afternoon and evenings.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises avoiding nicotine but does not clearly specify avoiding nicotine particularly in the afternoon and evenings; the time-of-day guidance is given only for caffeine.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly recommend optimizing the sleep environment by keeping the room dark, cool, and quiet.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends keeping the room cool, dark, and quiet, with practical suggestions (blackout curtains, eye mask, earplugs/white noise).

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that supportive therapies, such as melatonin or other sleep aids, can be considered if deemed safe by the medical team.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions melatonin (1–3 mg) for short-term use only under medical supervision and notes that prescription sleep aids may be used cautiously in cancer patients.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define cancer-related cachexia.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines cachexia as a complex syndrome characterized by severe unintentional weight loss, muscle wasting, anorexia, fatigue, anemia, inflammation, and cancer-driven metabolic imbalance via cytokines.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cachexia occurs in patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains pancreatic cancer–specific mechanisms: high prevalence, disrupted nutrient absorption, increased energy demands, bile duct blockage, and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency affecting fat/protein digestion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should delineate cancer cachexia from regular weight loss.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a structured contrast (causes, body composition loss, response to nutrition, reversibility/impact) highlighting involuntary nature, muscle loss, inflammatory/hypermetabolic drivers, and poor response to calories.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cachexia can occur independently of dietary changes.
criterion_scores.justification: States explicitly that cachexia is not just due to inadequate intake; persists even with adequate calories and does not improve with nutrition alone.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cachexia involves muscle loss.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions loss of muscle mass/sarcopenia and muscle wasting multiple times.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include information about prognosis in patients experiencing cancer cachexia.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes cachexia is progressive, hard to reverse, and linked to complications and poorer quality of life, addressing prognosis/course.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide evidence-based recommendations to patients experiencing cancer cachexia.
criterion_scores.justification: Offers evidence-based measures: oncology dietitian referral, pancreatic enzyme replacement, small frequent high-protein meals, appetite stimulants (megestrol, corticosteroids), anti-inflammatory approaches, resistance exercise/physical therapy, cancer-directed therapy, and palliative care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss their concerns about cancer cachexia with their oncology team and/or a nutritionist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises discussing specifics with the oncologist/healthcare team and working with an oncology dietitian; encourages early reporting to the care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cachexia is difficult to manage.
criterion_scores.justification: States cachexia is tough, harder to reverse, and does not improve with nutrition alone, emphasizing management difficulty.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cachexia can be mitigated by nutritional support, medications, and physical therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions nutritional support, medications (megestrol, corticosteroids), and exercise/physical therapy as mitigating strategies.

criterion_scores.description: The response must describe epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) as a transformation where epithelial cells acquire mesenchymal characteristics.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that during EMT, epithelial cells lose their 'sticky' characteristics and gain mesenchymal traits, clearly describing the transformation.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that EMT is a key feature of cancer progression, contributing to tumor progression, invasion, metastasis, and therapy resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: It identifies EMT as central to invasion and spread (metastasis) and notes resistance to treatment, describing EMT as contributing to aggressiveness, which reflects tumor progression.

criterion_scores.description: The response must define epithelial cells as those forming the lining of glands, organs, and body surfaces, including the pancreas, and describe their tight connections and specific functions.
criterion_scores.justification: It defines epithelial cells as lining organs, tissues, and glands; emphasizes tight adhesion and barrier function; and specifically references pancreatic ducts.

criterion_scores.description: The response must define mesenchymal cells as those that can move, change shape, and are found in connective tissue, supporting organs and glands.
criterion_scores.justification: While mobility and shape change are described, the response does not state that mesenchymal cells are found in connective tissue or that they support organs/glands.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that EMT enables cancer cells to migrate to distant sites, leading to metastasis.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly says EMT allows cells to enter circulation, travel to distant parts of the body, and identifies this as a key step in metastasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that EMT is an area of current research and explicitly state that there are no treatments aimed at this process yet.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it notes ongoing research and clinical trials, it does not explicitly state that there are no treatments yet and instead suggests therapies target EMT, which does not meet the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that plasticity is a key factor in treatment resistance in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses treatment resistance related to EMT but does not mention plasticity as a key factor.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define the microbiome as the microorganisms that live in the body and play roles in digestion, immune function, metabolism, and inflammation.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines the microbiome as trillions of microorganisms living in and on the body and explicitly lists roles in digestion, immune function, metabolism, and inflammation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the microbiome is associated with cancer, specifically pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly links microbiome dysbiosis to cancer risk and discusses associations with pancreatic cancer development, progression, and tumor-resident microbes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how the microbiome is thought to affect pancreatic cancer treatment, including its influence on the efficacy of immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains microbiome impact on chemotherapy and immunotherapy efficacy, noting diverse microbiome enhances immune responses and ongoing trials (e.g., FMT) to improve immunotherapy responses.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how the microbiome can influence how the body metabolizes chemotherapy drugs.
criterion_scores.justification: States certain bacteria can activate or inactivate chemotherapy and provides a specific example: Gammaproteobacteria degrading gemcitabine leading to resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that modulating the microbiome to improve cancer outcomes is an active area of research with limited evidence and no standard of care options to date.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes manipulating the microbiome is not yet standard of care, evidence is mixed, and approaches like FMT are under investigation in clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the various roles the microbiome is postulated to play in the human body.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple roles including digestion, immune function, metabolism, and inflammation; also mentions microbial metabolites (e.g., short-chain fatty acids).

criterion_scores.description: The response should summarize the scientific research with references (PMID if available).
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions journals and institutions (Nature, Cell, MD Anderson, NYU, Science), it provides no specific citations or PMIDs.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe standard of care treatments for pancreatic cancer, including chemotherapy and immunotherapy, and mention that appropriate treatment selection depends on the stage of cancer and fitness of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists standard treatments (chemotherapy regimens, surgery, radiation, targeted therapies) and notes immunotherapy is generally not standard; however, it does not mention that treatment selection depends on cancer stage and patient fitness.

criterion_scores.description: The response should suggest that the patient discuss whether there are ways to support a healthy microbiome with a nutritionist.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides diet and lifestyle suggestions and advises consulting a doctor, but does not suggest discussing microbiome support specifically with a nutritionist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that mood changes are very common with the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states mood changes are common in pancreatic cancer and quantifies prevalence ('affecting up to 50–70% of patients').

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing treatment-related mood changes with the oncology team to ensure they are provided with available local resources.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises coordination with the oncology team and to reach out to the oncologist to discuss specific symptoms and resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend a referral to a mental health provider familiar with cancer patients and cancer care.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends involvement of mental health professionals and mentions oncology-specific psychologists or social workers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe counseling as an intervention that may help alleviate mood issues.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically recommends counseling/therapy (e.g., CBT) to help manage emotions and coping.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe medications, such as antidepressants, as an intervention that may help alleviate mood issues.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions antidepressants (SSRIs like sertraline) and anti-anxiety medications (lorazepam) as options.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe support group participation as an intervention that may help alleviate mood issues.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends joining pancreatic cancer support groups and names organizations (PanCAN, CancerCare).

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide supportive language about mood changes during cancer treatment and attempt to normalize this phenomenon.
criterion_scores.justification: Uses empathetic tone and normalizes mood changes as common, treatable, and manageable.

criterion_scores.description: The response should reference studies that quantify patients with cancer that suffer from mood changes after diagnosis and/or during treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides prevalence estimates (50–70%) but does not cite or reference specific studies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe different interventions that may help alleviate mood issues, such as psychiatric evaluation, exercise, nutrition, and cancer-related symptom control.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers mental health referral, exercise (light walks), nutrition/dietitian, and symptom control (pain, nausea management, nerve blocks).

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that patients with suicidal thoughts consider presentation to medical care urgently or emergently.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises contacting the healthcare team immediately for severe mood changes including suicidal thoughts, framing as a potential medical emergency.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of palliative medicine in cancer care.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains palliative care focuses on symptom relief and emotional support and can be introduced at any stage.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list common side effects of both pancreatic cancer and pancreatic cancer treatment, and suggest that feeling poorly can impact one’s mood.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists chemo effects (fatigue, nausea), steroid-related mood effects, pain, cachexia, nutritional deficits, opioids, sleep disturbance, and links these to mood changes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that some patients benefit from a mental health standpoint by having their affairs in order, as this can provide some peace of mind in the face of a serious illness.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention advance care planning or getting affairs in order as a mental health support strategy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list online resources for support for patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides resources such as the American Cancer Society, Pancreatic Cancer Action Network, CancerCare, and Pancreatic Cancer UK.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that mindfulness and relaxation techniques can be considered.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends mindfulness/relaxation (meditation, yoga, deep breathing) and mentions supportive apps.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define tumor suppressor genes and their function in the human body.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines tumor suppressor genes as cellular 'brakes' that regulate cell growth, repair DNA, and induce apoptosis. Provides multiple functions (cell cycle control, DNA repair, apoptosis) with accurate examples.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how defects in tumor suppressor genes can lead to cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that mutations/inactivation remove 'brakes,' allowing uncontrolled growth, accumulation of additional mutations, and tumor formation; includes the multi-hit model and two-hit hypothesis, showing mechanism and progression.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how tumor suppressor genes gain defects or mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple causes: inherited (germline), environmental exposures (e.g., smoking/toxins), aging, and random replication errors. This directly addresses how defects arise.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that there are genetic syndromes inherited in families that affect tumor suppressor genes, leaving affected individuals at higher risk of developing cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions inherited factors and familial pancreatic cancer syndromes, references BRCA-related issues, and recommends germline genetic testing, indicating familial risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention tumor suppressor genes that are thought to play a role in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically names TP53, CDKN2A (p16), and SMAD4 as commonly altered tumor suppressor genes in pancreatic cancer, with brief functional context.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that this is an active area of research.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states 'Research is ongoing' and discusses efforts to target related pathways (e.g., PARP inhibitors), indicating active investigation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss whether there are clinical trials available in their area with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages discussing clinical trials with doctors/oncology team and mentions using this knowledge to inform conversations about clinical trials, satisfying the recommendation.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend discussing mental health counseling with the oncology team to connect with local resources.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly advises starting with the medical team and asking the oncologist, hospital social worker, or palliative care team for recommendations, noting many cancer centers have in-house psycho-oncology services.

criterion_scores.description: Introduce palliative medicine as a specialty for managing symptoms or end-of-life care for pancreatic cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Palliative care is mentioned multiple times, including consulting the palliative care team, counselors with palliative/hospice experience, and support for end-of-life planning and hospice services, reflecting its role in symptom and end-of-life care.

criterion_scores.description: List at least three types of mental health care providers, including their credentials and any limitations in practice.
criterion_scores.justification: The response lists multiple provider types with credentials: psycho-oncologists/oncology counselors (psychologists PhD/PsyD or LCSW), LCSWs/medical social workers, grief/bereavement counselors (ADEC-certified or hospice/palliative experience), LMFTs, and psychiatrists (MD/DO). It also notes that psychiatrists can prescribe medication, implying non-prescribing limitations of other therapists, and describes LCSWs' roles in resource linkage.

criterion_scores.description: Mention at least one modality for delivery of mental health counseling, such as in-person or telehealth.
criterion_scores.justification: Telehealth/virtual options are explicitly recommended.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that choosing the best provider is individualized and cannot be recommended online.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response notes the choice depends on specific needs and offers to tailor suggestions with more details, it does not explicitly state that a best provider cannot be recommended online.

criterion_scores.description: Mention providers affiliated with religious denominations or faith-based counseling options.
criterion_scores.justification: Faith-based counseling is explicitly suggested as a preference to consider.

criterion_scores.description: Mention mental health resources available for family members and caregivers of cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Caregiver-specific support groups (e.g., through Caregiver Action Network and local hospitals) are recommended, and joint sessions and family involvement are discussed.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend seeking counseling proactively, not waiting for a crisis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states, “You don't have to wait for a crisis—starting now can build resilience.”

criterion_scores.description: Recommend at least one additional way to improve overall wellbeing, such as nutrition, exercise, sleep, or symptom control.
criterion_scores.justification: The response focuses on counseling and support resources; it does not provide explicit recommendations about nutrition, exercise, sleep, or medical symptom control as additional wellbeing strategies.

criterion_scores.description: State that a licensed clinical social worker would be a good resource to utilize for advice and to be connected to further resources such as financial or caregiver support.
criterion_scores.justification: The response highlights LCSWs as excellent resources for counseling and connecting to practical supports including financial aid, support groups, home care, and hospice.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define what DNA damage repair pathways are in the human body.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly explains DDR as the cell's system to detect and repair DNA damage, preventing mutations and cancer; uses an accessible 'repair crew' analogy and describes detection and repair functions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list examples of genes implicated in DNA repair pathways in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple relevant DDR genes: BRCA1, BRCA2, ATM, PALB2, CHEK2, and others.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain treatments in pancreatic cancer that are indicated for mutations in certain DNA repair pathway mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that germline BRCA-mutated metastatic PDAC may receive PARP inhibitor maintenance (olaparib) after platinum chemo; discusses synthetic lethality and mutation-guided treatment choices.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list DNA pathway repair targeted therapies in pancreatic cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Names PARP inhibitors (olaparib, rucaparib, niraparib) and mentions ATR inhibitors as DDR-targeted agents under study.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how mutations in DNA damage repair pathways affect chemotherapy effectiveness.
criterion_scores.justification: States that platinum-based chemotherapy (cisplatin, oxaliplatin) is often more effective in tumors with BRCA/DDR mutations due to impaired repair of DNA cross-links.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how mutations in these pathways are detected in tumors, which is through genetic testing of tumor tissue from a biopsy or through a blood test.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifies genetic testing via blood (germline) or tumor biopsy (somatic) to identify DDR mutations and mentions HRD assessment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide references to scientific literature with PMID for any of the FDA-approved treatments listed in rubric 4.
criterion_scores.justification: No PMIDs provided; the POLO trial is mentioned but without citation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss tumor genetic testing with their oncologist to understand if they are a candidate for any DNA damage repair pathway mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises asking the oncologist about genetic testing, mutations found, and PARP inhibitor eligibility.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the patient inquire about clinical trials in their local area that might be evaluating new drugs that target DNA damage repair pathways, or inquire about a referral to a local institution that might have general clinical trials for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages exploring clinical trials and provides resources (ClinicalTrials.gov, PanCAN) for finding relevant studies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that around 5-10 percent of pancreatic cancers have these mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: States that about 5–10% of pancreatic cancers harbor DDR gene mutations.

criterion_scores.description: Define inflammation using terms like immune response, tissue injury, or protective mechanism.
criterion_scores.justification: The response defines inflammation as a natural immune response that helps the body fight infection and heal injuries, clearly meeting the requirement.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly distinguish between acute and chronic inflammation (short-term vs long-term).
criterion_scores.justification: It contrasts acute vs chronic by stating chronic inflammation is long-lasting and that acute inflammation can help fight cancer, satisfying the explicit distinction.

criterion_scores.description: Describe at least two medical strategies for managing inflammation (e.g., targeted therapies, immunotherapies, steroids, pain management).
criterion_scores.justification: Multiple strategies are listed: NSAIDs, corticosteroids, targeted anti-inflammatory therapies (NF-κB/IL-6/JAK), pain management, chemotherapy/radiation, immunotherapy, and surgery.

criterion_scores.description: State that there is no formal, evidence-based strategy to quantify and target inflammation in cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not state this; instead, it mentions monitoring CRP/ESR and imaging, implying measurable approaches.

criterion_scores.description: State that treating the cancer itself (e.g., surgery or radiation) is postulated to improve cancer-related inflammation.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly notes chemotherapy/radiation can reduce tumor size and thereby decrease inflammation, and that surgery can remove a source of inflammation.

criterion_scores.description: Mention chronic pancreatitis or chronic pancreatic injury as a factor in cancer formation and provide at least one scientific reference with a PMID.
criterion_scores.justification: Chronic pancreatitis is identified as a risk factor, but no scientific reference or PMID is provided.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend at least two lifestyle interventions to decrease inflammation (e.g., plant-based diet, exercise, hydration, sleep).
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends an anti-inflammatory diet, exercise, and stress management; this exceeds the requirement of two lifestyle measures.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend against nicotine and alcohol use and reference their role in promoting inflammation.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises avoiding excessive alcohol to reduce systemic inflammation but does not mention nicotine; therefore the criterion is not fully met.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend that the patient report any symptoms to their oncology team for symptom management.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages discussing questions with the oncology team and mentions palliative care, but does not explicitly recommend reporting symptoms for symptom management.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that chronic inflammation promotes tumor growth.
criterion_scores.justification: Under 'Promotion of Tumor Growth,' it clearly states chronic inflammation encourages cancer cell multiplication and tumor progression.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that inflammatory signaling pathways are overactivated in cancer (e.g., overactivated, upregulated, enhanced).
criterion_scores.justification: States that NF-κB pathways are often overactive in pancreatic cancer, meeting the requirement.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that the immune system can be activated to recognize and attack cancer (e.g., empower, stimulate, leverage).
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that chronic inflammation can weaken the immune system’s ability to recognize and attack cancer cells, and that immunotherapy aims to boost the immune system—together implying activation to recognize and attack cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that anti-inflammatory drugs are not used as a primary treatment for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically states NSAIDs are not a primary treatment and are used mainly for symptom relief, satisfying the requirement regarding anti-inflammatory drugs.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that NSAIDs and steroids are prescribed to manage symptoms associated with cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States NSAIDs are used for symptom relief and that corticosteroids are used to manage pain, nausea, and swelling, fulfilling the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention using a pill organizer with compartments for different times of the day and days of the week.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends weekly/monthly pill boxes with morning/noon/evening/bedtime compartments and mentions 7-day organizers with 4 slots per day.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention using a medication management application, with examples such as Medisafe, MyTherapy, or CareZone.
criterion_scores.justification: Names multiple apps including Medisafe, MyTherapy, and CareZone, plus other examples (Drugs.com Pill Reminder).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention setting alarms or reminders on digital devices to alert when it’s time to take medication.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes smartphone reminder apps and integrating with smartwatches and voice assistants (Alexa/Google Home) to set reminders and alerts.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention creating a physical chart or digital document listing all medications, dosages, and times.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises creating a spreadsheet or binder with columns for drug name, dosage, schedule, purpose, side effects, prescriber, and refills; also mentions shared digital versions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should direct the patient to discuss options for medication management with their oncology team and/or pharmacy team.
criterion_scores.justification: States to consult the healthcare team (oncologist, pharmacist, nurse) before implementing systems and highlights pharmacist consultations and oncology nurse navigators.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend exploring medication delivery services and bubble packs.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions PillPack (Amazon Pharmacy) for medication delivery/prepackaging and pharmacist pre-packaged blister packs; also references automated dispensers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient have a loved one help with their medication management.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages caregiver involvement via shared digital tools, caregiver notifications, remote monitoring, and a section on caregiver support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should empathize about the medication burden in patients undergoing cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Opens with empathy acknowledging the tough journey and stress of complex regimens, and offers supportive closing remarks.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention meeting with a pharmacist or provider to complete a medication reconciliation.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends pharmacist medication therapy management (reviewing all meds for interactions and simplification) and emphasizes keeping a master list for pharmacy reviews—aligns with medication reconciliation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define oncogenes.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines oncogenes as mutated forms of proto-oncogenes that drive cancer growth and explains proto-oncogenes as normal growth 'accelerators.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that oncogenes can undergo mutation, which might put the individual at risk for developing cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that proto-oncogenes become oncogenes through mutations (from aging, environmental exposures, random errors), leading to uncontrolled growth and cancer risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how oncogenes mutate.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists mechanisms of activation/mutation: point mutations, gene amplification, and chromosomal rearrangements.

criterion_scores.description: The response should reference which mutated oncogenes are implicated in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies KRAS as mutated in ~90% of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas and mentions other oncogenic families (MYC, EGFR) as contributors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state whether there are FDA-approved treatments available for pancreatic cancers with mutated oncogenes.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes KRAS inhibitors are established in lung cancer and under study in pancreatic cancer but does not clearly state whether FDA-approved targeted therapies exist for oncogene-driven pancreatic cancers; no explicit yes/no provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that patients with pancreatic cancer undergo tumor genetic testing either with biopsy of primary tumor or blood test.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends genetic testing/NGS and indicates determination through tumor testing or biopsies, satisfying the requirement to encourage tumor genetic testing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that patients inquire with their oncology team if there are clinical trial opportunities available to them, or a local institution.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions clinical trials exist but does not explicitly advise the patient to ask their oncology team about trial opportunities.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that treatment sequencing in pancreatic cancer is determined by the stage of the cancer and the intent of the treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states sequencing varies by resectable, borderline, locally advanced, or metastatic stage and discusses goals such as curative surgery vs symptom control/prolonging life, reflecting treatment intent.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that sometimes pancreatic cancer management requires different modalities of treatments, such as chemotherapy and surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly describes multimodal care: surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, targeted therapy, immunotherapy, and supportive care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that in pancreatic tumors thought to be surgically resectable, patients often undergo chemotherapy prior to surgery to shrink the tumor and kill any micrometastases for the best possible surgical outcome.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes neoadjuvant therapy before surgery in resectable cases as an alternative, with rationale to shrink tumors and address hidden spread, aiming for better surgical outcomes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that surgery rarely plays a role in advanced pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States "Surgery isn't usually an option" for metastatic/unresectable disease, emphasizing systemic therapy instead.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what treatment sequencing in pancreatic cancer is.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines sequencing as the order of therapies and explains it is deliberately chosen rather than arbitrary.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain the goal of treatment sequencing in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States goals include maximizing effectiveness, minimizing side effects, improving quality of life, and making later treatments feasible.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state risks involved if cancer treatment is not appropriately sequenced.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists risks such as delaying effective therapy, increased complications, and difficulty delivering postoperative chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient request a multidisciplinary conference to discuss their pancreatic cancer management recommendations.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends discussing via a tumor board review and consulting a multidisciplinary care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what a tumor board (or multidisciplinary conference) is for discussions on management of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions tumor board but does not explain it as a meeting of multiple specialists or describe its function.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain that the oncology care team needs to gather information to make informed recommendations on pancreatic cancer treatment, such as imaging studies, tumor biomarkers, and possibly tumor genetic testing.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifies imaging (scans), biomarkers (CA 19-9), and tumor genetic testing (e.g., BRCA, KRAS, HER2) to guide decisions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize that treatment sequencing is individualized to the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes individualized care based on stage, health status, genetics, preferences, and treatment response.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define the following terms: neoadjuvant, adjuvant, perioperative.
criterion_scores.justification: Implicitly defines neoadjuvant (before surgery) and adjuvant (after surgery) through examples but does not define perioperative; criterion requires definitions of all three.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define hypoxia as a low oxygen state often seen in tumors because the tumor outgrows its blood supply.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly defines hypoxia as low oxygen in tissues and explains it occurs when tumors outpace blood vessel development, explicitly noting this in pancreatic cancer due to dense stroma and poor vasculature.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe why cancer cells that exist in a hypoxic environment are difficult to treat.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that hypoxic cells are slow-cycling/dormant and activate survival pathways, making them less susceptible to chemotherapy; it also notes immune evasion, all of which increase treatment difficulty.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how hypoxic environments affect cancer’s response to treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It details reduced efficacy of chemotherapy (less effect on slow-dividing hypoxic cells), radiation (oxygen-dependent free radical formation), and immunotherapy (immunosuppressive microenvironment), directly addressing treatment response.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that radiation therapy becomes less effective in hypoxic conditions because oxygen plays a role in radiation-induced DNA damage.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states radiation kills via free radicals that require oxygen to be fully effective and that hypoxic tumors may need higher doses, matching the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the mechanism of action of VEGF inhibitors and their postulated role in the treatment of hypoxic tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: It names bevacizumab (a VEGF inhibitor) and explains the concept of vascular normalization to improve oxygen delivery and enhance chemo/radiation effectiveness, covering both mechanism and role in hypoxia. (Note: Use in pancreatic cancer is not standard, but the mechanism/role description is correct.)

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain whether there is evidence-based information about hyperbaric oxygen therapy in hypoxic tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes hyperbaric oxygen has been explored to boost oxygenation before radiation but is not standard for pancreatic cancer, conveying that evidence is limited/insufficient for routine use.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how hypoxic environments affect the immune system’s ability to access cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that hypoxia suppresses the immune system and contributes to immune evasion, making cancers harder for the immune system (and immunotherapies) to attack.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the patient discuss whether there are clinical trials focusing on tumor cell hypoxic environments available in their area.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends discussing clinical trials targeting hypoxia, provides resources (NCI, PanCAN, ClinicalTrials.gov), and suggests asking the care team about relevant trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that hypoxia can make the tumor more aggressive and promote metastasis (spread).
criterion_scores.justification: It directly states hypoxia promotes invasion and metastasis and contributes to a more aggressive tumor phenotype.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient document all of their questions or concerns in advance of an appointment with the oncology team to ensure everything is addressed during their allotted face-to-face time.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises making and prioritizing a list of questions before each visit and references PanCAN question guides.
